questions.text: A surgery resident during the rounds advised the intern to monitor the burns patient for adequate fluid resuscitation and also instructed him to give a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight if the patient showed signs of hypoperfusion. All of the following are indications to give bolus fluid except _______
questions.solution:
A high hematocrit (not low) is an indicator of hypoperfusion.

Urine output is the best measure to monitor for the adequacy of fluid resuscitation. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour.

  • If the urine output is below this, the infusion rate should be increased by 50%.
  • If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given.

Signs of hypoperfusion include,

  1. Restlessness with tachycardia,
  2. Cool peripheries and
  3. High hematocrit

questions.text:
The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
  1. Glasgow coma scale
  2. Respiratory Rate
  3. Pulse Rate
  4. Systolic BP
  5. Mechanism of Injury
questions.solution:
The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient.

Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

The score range is 0–12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury. 

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 3 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue shows Hurthle cells. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre may be seen
  • Hurthle/ Askanazy cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles

 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45 - 65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of a Ryle's tube?
questions.solution:
The best position for a conscious patient to be in during the insertion of Ryle's tube is sitting with neck flexion.

RT, also known as nasogastric (NG) tube, measures 120-125 cm. It has 4 markings at 40cm (cardia), 50cm (body), 60cm (pylorus), and 70 cm (duodenum) to indicate the approximate position after the placement.

Indications for NG tube:

  • Feeding in patients with dysphagia, decreased appetite, or those who are nil per os (NPO) for medical or surgical reasons.
  • Aspiration of gastric fluid
  • Gastric decompression in cases of intestinal obstruction and paralytic ileus.
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome 
  • Bowel irrigation

The absolute contraindications for an NG tube are severe midface trauma, recent nasal surgery, and basilar skull fractures

Steps for the correct insertion of RT in an adult:

  1. Examination of the patient’s nostril for any anatomical abnormalities and then instillation with 10 ml of 1% lignocaine 
  2. NEX method is used to measure the length of the RT:  Place the exit port of the tube at the tip of the nose. Extend the tube to the earlobe, and then to the xiphisternum.
  3. The patient is asked to sit upright with partial neck flexion. The tip of the Ryle’s tube is lubricated and passed along the floor of the nasal passage until a resistance is felt(corresponds to nasopharynx)
  4. The patient is subsequently asked to swallow water to guide the tube through the esophagus into the stomach until the marked length (based on the NEX method).
  5. NG tube is finally taped to secure it in place.

Confirmation of the correct position is done by

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • X-ray Chest
  • Colorimetric capnography

questions.text: A 44-year-old female cook presents with a 1-year history of dyspnea, episodic cough, wheeze, shortness of breath, and chest tightness.  What is the best way to diagnose bronchial asthma in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best way to diagnose bronchial asthma is by the demonstration of reversible obstruction of the airways.

Wheeze, dyspnoea, and reduced FEV1 values are nonspecific indicators of airway obstruction and are seen in any of the obstructive pathologies (i.e. asthma, COPD, and bronchiectasis). Therefore, they do not independently diagnose asthma.

Whereas, the administration of an inhaled beta 2 agonist can differentiate between Asthma and COPD as follows:

  • ≥12% (≥200ml) increase in the FEV1 demonstrates the reversibility of airway obstruction which is diagnostic of bronchial asthma.
  • <12% or no increase in FEV1 demonstrates the irreversibility component of airway obstruction indicating COPD.

questions.text: A patient presents with increased frequency of micturition, incomplete bladder emptying, and frequent urinary tract infections. What is the diagnosis based on the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the X-ray gives the diagnosis of bladder stones. The tip of a catheter can also be seen in the Xray.

Primary bladder stone:

  • Develops in sterile urine in the absence of any known functional, anatomic, or infectious factors and does not necessarily imply that stones have formed de novo in the bladder.
  • Most common in children younger than 10 years of age
  • Most vesical calculi are mixed
  • Ammonium acid urate, calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate are the most common components of primary bladder calculi

Secondary bladder stone: Forms during infection, due to bladder outflow obstruction, impaired bladder emptying, or the presence of a foreign body.

Types:

  • Calcium oxalate stones
  • Uric acid stones - occur in patients with gout but are also observed in patients with ileostomies or with bladder outlet obstruction
  • Cystine stones - in cystinuria
  • Triple phosphate stones - occur in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

questions.text: A young woman suspected to have genital tuberculosis underwent an endometrial biopsy. She received a report confirming her diagnosis within a few hours. Which of the following diagnostic methods was most likely used here?
questions.solution:
As the report was received so fast, nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) was the likely method used as it can detect mycobacteria within a few hours. It also detects if the bacteria are resistant to rifampicin. 

Diode based fluorescent microscopy (LED FM) is a highly sensitive and specific method to diagnose tuberculosis. However, it requires 2-8 weeks to yield results and hence does not help in early diagnosis.

The BACTEC MGIT 960 is a fully automated, non-radiometric system used to diagnose TB. It uses the fluorescence of an oxygen sensor to detect the growth of mycobacteria in culture. It takes 13-14 days to give results.

The BACTEC 460 TB is a semiautomated, radiometric system where a radio-active carbon-labelled substrate such as palmitic acid or formic acid is used as a marker for detecting bacterial growth. It takes 14-15 days to detect mycobacteria in culture.

Other methods that can be used to diagnose genital TB are:

  • Semen culture can be done for vulvovaginal tuberculosis. It takes a longer duration with unsatisfactory results as compared to the other methods.
  • Gas chromatography involves direct demonstration of compounds characteristic of mycobacteria. It is 90% sensitive and provides a rapid diagnosis. However, it is expensive and not commonly done.

questions.text: The image given below shows _______
questions.solution:
The sonographic image depicts Twin peak/Lambda sign. 

The placenta is seen extending between the amnion layers, forming a 'peak'.

It confirms dichorionic pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lignocaine is false?

choices.text: It blocks active sodium channels with more affinity than resting sodium channels
It can be given orally for cardiac arrhythmias
It's duration of action is increased by adrenaline

questions.solution:
Lignocaine is used for cardiac arrhythmias but is not effective orally because of high first-pass metabolism.

Option A: Local anaesthetics have more affinity for active sodium channels over resting channels.

Option B: Lignocaine use can result in cardiac toxicity especially at higher doses where it interferes with impulse conduction.

Option D: Vasoconstrictor like adrenaline increases the duration of action of lignocaine when used for infiltration anaesthesia.

questions.text: What structure involved in parotid gland surgery is shown by the arrow?
questions.solution:
• The structure shown is the main trunk of the facial nerve.
  • The facial nerve can be identified during parotid surgery by using certain landmarks. These landmakrs are as follows:
    • The inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. This is termed a Conley's pointer and indicates the position of the facial nerve, which lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
    • The upper border of the posterior belly of the digastric
  • It can also be identified by tracing the nerve back from its terminal branches and by using a nerve stimulator.
  • Frey syndrome (gustatory sweating) results from damage to the autonomous innervation of the salivary gland with inappropriate regeneration of parasympathetic nerve fibers that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin.
    • It is diagnosed by the starch-iodine test.

questions.text: A middle age male patient presented with complaints of palpitations. The patient's ECG tracing is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. It is common in men and risk factors are age, underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, and obesity.

Features include heart rate typically ranging from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place.

Typically, ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent p waves.

Management is mainly by controlling rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifying risk factors. 

Related Pearl: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia

 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes

 

Ventricular flutter

 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: A young patient is being administered cardiopulmonary resuscitation as per appropriate guidelines. Which of the following is an indicator of low-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation?

choices.text: Chest compressions at the rate of 100-120/min
End tidal carbon dioxide <10 mm Hg
End tidal carbon dioxide >20 mm Hg

questions.solution:
CPR quality needs to be improved when end-tidal CO2(ETCO2) is less than 10 mm Hg. CPR can be considered to be high quality when ETCO2 is at least 10-20 mmHg.

ETCO2 is the level of carbon dioxide that is released at the end of an exhaled breath. It can be monitored with the help of capnometry and capnography.

This parameter is used to monitor a patient's ventilation status in real-time. Failure to maintain ETCO2 at >10 mm Hg during adult CPR is a reflection of poor cardiac output and it is found to strongly predicts unsuccessful resuscitation.

 

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with painful swelling of the right calf muscle, 7 days after her knee replacement surgery. On examination, her heart rate is 70 beats per min, her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and her SpO2 is 96% on room air. Homan's test is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of deep venous thrombosis(DVT).

Deep vein thrombosis:

Causes

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s sign
  • Inverted beer bottle sign/ champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Note:

Mose's sign- Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side-to-side is also painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender and this test is known as Moses’ sign.

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below. 

Treatment

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

Pulmonary embolism is the commonest complication of deep vein thrombosis leading to death.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for venous thromboembolism

Patient factors:

  • Age
  • Obesity
  • Varicose veins
  • Immobility
  • Pregnancy
  • Puerperium
  • High-dose estrogen therapy
  • Previous deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

Thrombophilia

  • Congenital
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III, protein C or protein S
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant
    • Factor V leiden gene defect or activated protein C resistance
    • Dysfibrinogenaemias
  • Acquired
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant

Disease or surgical procedure

  • Trauma or surgery, especially of pelvis, hip, and lower limb
  • Malignancy, especially pelvic, and abdominal metastatic
  • Heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Paralysis of lower limb(s) infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Polycythaemia
  • Paraproteinaemia
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Behçet’s disease
  • Homocysteinemia

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients on monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI) + selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) can develop serotonin syndrome, which is characterized by fever, clonus, hyperreflexia, and tremors.

Serotonin syndrome can occur with any drug that increases 5-HT levels (e.g., MAOIs, SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA, and dextromethorphan). Coadministration of these drugs results in increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels, which are responsible for the autonomic symptoms seen in serotonin syndrome.

It is characterized by 3 A’s:

  • Neuromuscular hyperActivity- clonus, hyperreflexia, hypertonia, tremor, and seizure
  • Autonomic stimulation - hyperthermia, diaphoresis, diarrhea 
  • Agitation

Treatment: Cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist).

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

 Syndrome
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Serotonin syndrome
Anticholinergic syndrome
Malignant hyperthermia
 Cause
Dysregulation of dopaminergic pathways
Co-prescription of MAO-I and SSRIs leading to increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels
Anticholinergic intoxication
Halogenated anesthetics and succinylcholine leading to a
hypermetabolic response causing an increased intracellular calcium level
Fever and altered mental status

give dantrolene, bromocriptine and monitor CPK levels
Change the drug; 
give cyproheptadine

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with type 1 renal tubular acidosis?

choices.text: Urinary pH is < 5.5 after acid loading

questions.solution:
Urinary pH will be > 5.5 after acid loading in RTA type 1.

In this condition, there is a defect in H+ secretion by the distal tubules. Hence, there is a failure of urine acidification and NH₄⁺ excretion. In the acid loading test, acidosis is induced by the administration of NH4Cl (releases H+). In normal individuals, this results in increased excretion of H+, leading to acidic urine (pH < 5.5). However, this fails to occur in RTA type 1.

Impaired secretion of H+ leads to potassium wasting and hypokalemia (via the H+/K+ATPase antiporter). The resulting metabolic acidosis causes bone demineralization and resorption.

questions.text: The stage of bedsore given in the following image is?
questions.solution:
The stage of the given bedsore is Stage 4. The given image shows complete skin loss that involves muscles and shows exposed bone indicating a stage 4 pressure sore.

 Stage       Description
 1  Non- blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
 2 Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis.
3

Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4

Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

Below is the image showing the stages of pressure sore.

Related Pearl: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text: Which type of non-union does the given radiograph signify?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows hypertrophic nonunion of the tibia.

Although the enlarged fracture ends suggest active osteogenesis, the gap is not bridged because of inadequate stability. Such non-unions have adequate vascularity and display abundant callus.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Atrophic nonunion
  • Oligotrophic nonunion
  • Hypertrophic nonunion

Pseudoarthrosis has features of hypertrophic nonunion, but due to excessive and chronic motility, there is formation of a pseudo-capsule containing fluid similar to an actual synovial joint.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the casualty with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. His blood sugar levels are 421 mg/dl and his urine ketones are 3+. He is started on IV normal saline and insulin infusion. Which of the following electrolyte abnormality should he be monitored for?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis, which is treated with insulin infusion. Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis are at risk for developing hypokalemia after the initiation of treatment.

Diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) is a life-threatening condition characterized by elevated blood sugar levels and ketosis. Patients present with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, confusion, and abdominal pain.

DKA is managed with a combination of intravenous fluids, insulin, and potassium correction.

At presentation, these patients have normal to high potassium levels in spite of excessive potassium loss. This is because potassium moves out from the cell to the extracellular space as a result of acidosis.

Once insulin is administered and acidosis is corrected, the potassium ion flows back into the cells causing hypokalemia. Hence the physician should be vigilant and initiate intravenous potassium correction once insulin is given to the patient.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent TURP.  An hour later, he was found to have an altered sensorium and had several bouts of vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause for the above symptoms is water intoxication also known as transurethral resection of the prostrate (TURP) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may present with confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 

Management:

  • Fluid restriction.
  • Use of isotonic glycine for irrigation during resection.

questions.text: A patient presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. Manometry was done, which showed simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). The probable diagnosis is_______.
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture and manometric findings are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm - It is a poorly understood hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women.  Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles.

Investigations :

A barium swallow shows corkscrew esophagus. 

However, manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis.

  • On classic manometry - simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) are suggestive of DES (as given in the question).
  • On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (Distal contractile Integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. This is in accordance with the latest Chicago classification.

Treatment: Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Surgical treatment includes extended/long oesophageal myotomy, up to the aortic arch, if required. The surgical treatment of DES is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

The older terms "diffuse esophageal spasm" and "jackhammer (nutcracker ) esophagus" have been replaced in the Chicago classification by Distal esophageal spasm and Hypercontractile esophagus respectively. 

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions

questions.text: A man was working at a construction site on a hot summer afternoon when he suddenly collapsed. His coworkers said there was no history of sweating. On examination, the patient was tachycardic, tachypneic, and hypotensive. The doctor found that the rectal temperature was 42ºC.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is heat stroke.

Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition occurring due to cerebral dysfunction when the core temperature is over 40 degrees celsius.

Classic heat stroke occurs in patients with impaired thermoregulation or those that are exposed to extreme environmental conditions. 

Exertional heat stroke occurs in healthy persons taking part in strenuous physical activity in a hot or humid environment.

Patients present with abnormalities such as tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, and widened pulse pressure. In certain cases, patients may also exhibit premonitory psychiatry symptoms and ataxia.

Other options:

Option A: Heat cramps are painful skeletal muscle spasms that occur during or immediately after exercise.

Option B: Heat syncope is a transient loss of consciousness in patients who have been standing for a long duration in a hot or humid environment.

questions.text: A young female patient with a history of amenorrhea for 6 weeks presented with vaginal spotting, sharp abdominal pain, and abdominal tenderness.  A urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy.  Where is the most common location of implantation?
questions.solution:
The most common location of implantation in ectopic pregnancy is the ampulla.

A pregnancy is considered ectopic when there is the implantation of the blastocyst at a site other than the endometrial lining of the uterus. In nearly 95% of these pregnancies, implantation occurs in the fallopian tube. The commonest site in the fallopian tube is the ampulla.

This patient with 6-week history of amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and an empty uterus is likely to have an ectopic pregnancy. In addition, sharp abdominal pain, vaginal spotting, and abdominal tenderness support a diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. 

The other sites of implantations are the ovary, cervix, or prior cesarean scar.  

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: A 6-year-old fully immunized healthy boy suddenly develops a high fever along with difficulty swallowing. The child is unwilling to lie down and sits with his chin up, and mouth open. Noisy breathing is also noted. Lateral radiographs of the neck demonstrate the finding shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a immunized child with high fever, difficulty swallowing, noisy breathing, and a lateral radiograph showing a thumb sign points towards the diagnosis of acute epiglottitis.

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis and presents with high fever, severe sore throat, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically leans forward while sitting for ease of breathing.

The diagnosis is often made bedside. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (Thumb sign). The below image shows the thumb sign.

Treatment includes airway management followed by administration of antibiotics like ampicillin/sulbactam, cefotaxime, or ceftriaxone. 

Other options - 

Option A: Laryngeal diphtheria is unlikely to occur in a fully immunized child, and diphtheria is typically associated with membrane formation. 

Option B: Retropharyngeal abscess is seen secondary to infections and usually does not present with fever. Children usually present with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, lateral to the midline. It is confirmed by a lateral X-ray of the neck which shows a widening of the prevertebral shadow. 

Option D: Croup is usually gradual in onset and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms. Also, fever is usually absent in such patients.

questions.text: An unconscious young man was rushed to the emergency department. On examination, his heart rate was 190 beats/min and his blood pressure was 70/40 mmHg. His electrocardiogram is given below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electrocardiogram (ECG) showing narrow QRS complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). As the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the next step in management is DC (direct current) cardioversion.

PSVT is a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with sudden onset and termination. The patients mainly present with dizziness and palpitations. Evaluation of these patients includes monitoring of vitals and ECG.

Management is as follows:

1) When the patient is hemodynamically stable:

  • Carotid sinus massage can be done. It is avoided if carotid bruit is present and if there is a prior history of stroke.
  • Valsalva maneuver is done if the patient is cooperative
  • Intravenous adenosine is useful in most cases. However, its usage is contraindicated in patients with prior cardiac transplantation. It can aggravate bronchospasm and atrial fibrillation, hence must be used with great caution in such patients.
  • Intravenous calcium channel blockers such as verapamil or diltiazem and beta-blockers are helpful but can cause hypotension.

2) When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e. when the patient has hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text: A young female patient developed uterine prolapse soon after delivery as shown below. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate management of uterine prolapse in the postpartum period is ring pessary with pelvic floor exercise. 

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for the first few months postpartum. Surgery may be advised, if the prolaspe does not improve with conservative management.

The image below shows the various degrees of uterovaginal prolapse.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Congenital/ Nulliparous (young) uterine prolapse: Sling/ cervicopexy

Uterovaginal uterine prolapse:

>40 No No  Ward Mayo's vaginal hysterectomy
>60(medically unfit for hysterectomy)        -      - Le Forts repair
Prolapse during pregnancy /puerperium     -       - Ring Pessary

questions.text: A  female patient presents with severe abdominal pain and vomiting which was provisionally diagnosed as intestinal obstruction. An emergency laparotomy was done and the following specimen was removed. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of a trichobezoar, suggests a diagnosis of trichophagia.

Trichophagia is the compulsive eating of hair associated with trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is a form of obsessive-compulsive disorder that is associated with hair pulling. In trichophagia, people also ingest the hair that they pull. 

Complications of trichotillomania include:

  • trichobezoars
  • malnutrition
  • intestinal obstruction

Trichobezoar is a foreign body found in the gastrointestinal tract as a result of accumulated ingested hair.

The modalities currently used in the management of trichotillomania are cognitive behavioral therapy and habit reversal training.

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD with the following skin finding. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Eye and skeletal defects are seen

questions.solution:
The image shows cutaneous macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches, corresponding to the lines of Blaschko, suggestive of hypomelanosis of Ito.

It is a rare neuroectodermal disorder of pigmentation. It is associated with epilepsy and mental retardation. Extracutaneous findings include neurological, ophthalmological, and skeletal defects.

questions.text: A truck driver presents with dilated,tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot.What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP(Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)?
questions.solution:
Dilated tortuous veins of 4 mm indicate varicose veins, so the stage is C2.

questions.text: The finding shown in the image below is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image shows a chocolate cyst, which is seen in ovarian endometriosis.

The cysts form secondary to endometriotic implants in the ovarian stroma that bleed periodically and undergo shedding.

Spontaneous cyst rupture, with the release of thick, tarry brownish fluid, can lead to acute peritonitis, and this may be mistaken for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, appendicitis, diverticulitis, or torsion of a tumor.

Endometriosis is a condition that is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue in ectopic sites such as:

  • Ovary (chocolate cysts)- left/right lower quadrant pain
  • Pouch of Douglas - pain during defecation
  • Uterosacral ligaments - chronic pelvic pain & infertility
  • Appendix - right lower quadrant pain.
  • Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis
  • Umbilicus
  • Lung - cyclical hemoptysis.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: Which of the following formulates food standards for the international food market?
questions.solution:
The Codex Alimentarius Commission formulates food standards for the international market. It is the principal organ of the FAO/WHO food standards program.

The ISI standards (Indian Standards Institute) and AGMARK are the Indian food standards. They are based on the standards of Codex Alimentarius.

The PFA (Prevention of Food Adulteration) Act was introduced to provide protection from adulteration or contamination of food.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in:
questions.solution:
The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in protons.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm.

The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak.

The behavior of the proton can be precisely determined and the beam can be directed so the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumor site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest. 

Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

The Bragg curve shown below plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

questions.text: In a case of atonic PPH, a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative was given every 15 mins as a uterotonic. What is the maximum number of times the drug can be administered?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is a methyl PGF2 alpha derivative. The normal dosage is 0.25mg. The maximum dose is 2mg. 

So, 2/0.25 = 8 times.

Carboprost is a 15-methyl PGF2 alpha derivative used as a 2nd line drug in the treatment of PPH that is unresponsive to oxytocin. 

Side effects:

  • Diarrhoea
  • Hypertension
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting

Contraindications:

  • Bronchial asthma
  • Suspected amniotic fluid embolism
  • Active cardiac, renal or hepatic diseases.

questions.text: In a woman diagnosed with infertility, which of the following antihormonal substance can be used to induce ovulation?
questions.solution:
Clomiphene citrate is an antihormonal substance used to induce ovulation in a patient diagnosed with infertility. Ovulation can be induced by giving clomiphene citrate 50 mg daily, starting from day 2 to day 6 of the menstrual cycle for 5 days.

Related Pearl: Management of female infertility for different causes are as follows

Etiology Investigations Management  
Tubal cause
  • Hysterosalpingography or sonosalpingography
  • Falloscopy
  • Salpingography
  • Laparoscopic chromotubation
  • Laparoscopic adhesiolysis
  • Tuboplasty
  • Hysteroscopic cannulation and balloonplasty
  • If all the above procedures fail or not feasible go for IVF/GIFT 
Ovulation related           
  • Ovulation monitoring by ultrasound (BBT, BBI) And  Endometrial Biopsy for tuberculosis done    
  • If the above steps are abnormal, do a hormonal study
  • FSH, LH, Prolactin
  • E2, P level
  • Thyroid and diabetes
  • Clomiphene and letrozole
  • If it fails, give FSH, LH, GnRH
  • Check for a response; if there is no response do IVF Donor egg.
  • If all the above measures fail, the final option is to adopt  
Other causes   Ultrasound, MRI, SSG, hysteroscopy   Treat the cause

questions.text:
Which of the following are true for a screening test?

1) Done on apparently healthy

2) Applied to individuals

3) Time-consuming

4) Relatively inaccurate results

5) Based on one criterion/ cut off
questions.solution:
Screening tests are done on apparently healthy individuals, the results of the test are relatively inaccurate, the tests are based on one criterion.

The difference between screening and diagnostic tests is given below:

Screening test Diagnostic test

Done on apparently healthy

Done on patients with signs and symptoms

Applied to groups

Applied to single patients

Based on one criterion or cut-off point

Based on evaluation of a number of symptoms, signs, and laboratory findings

Less accurate

More accurate

Less expensive

More expensive

Not a basis for treatment

Used as a basis for treatment

The initiative comes from the investigator or agency providing care

The initiative comes from a patient with a complaint

Screening tests are recommended in the following conditions:

  • Early diagnosis changes the disease course
  • In a disease with an asymptomatic stage
  • In a disease with a test for diagnosis and treatment
  • The natural history of the disease is well known

questions.text: A young patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of icterus. The patient also gives a history of feeling stressed out due to work. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Gilbert's syndrome.

Gilbert's syndrome is a hereditary defect in bilirubin conjugation characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

A promoter region of the gene coding for the UDP-glucuronosyl transferase (UGT1A1) enzyme in Gilbert syndrome results in a variable rate of transcription of the normal enzyme. UGT1A1 activity is reduced to 10-33% of normal. It presents with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia with other liver function tests being normal. The disorder is precipitated by stress, alcohol, and reduced caloric intake.

Liver histology shows increased lipofuscin pigment.

Gilbert's syndrome doesn't require treatment. The bilirubin levels may fluctuate over time, and patients may occasionally have jaundice, which usually resolves on its own with no ill effects.

Other options:

Option A: Type I Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It usually presents as severe congenital jaundice and persists throughout life.

Options C and D: Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome both have elevated conjugated bilirubin in the blood, and are due to defective secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

questions.text: A carpenter presented to the outpatient department with a swelling over his palm as shown in the image below He gives a history of being injured by a nail on the same region during work.  Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an implantation dermoid which is caused due to traumatic injury.

Implantation dermoid is an acquired condition that occurs as the result of implantation of epidermal fragments into the dermis by a penetrating injury. The epidermis continues to grow and forms a cyst lined with stratified squamous epithelium and filled with keratin.

Can occur with any skin puncture, laceration, or skin incision which has the potential to implant epidermal elements into the dermis and subcutaneous tissue, where continued production of keratin and other epidermal products produces a thick-walled cyst.

Mostly seen in farmers, factory workers, carpenters, and tailors who are subject to repeated minor traumas to the hand. Risk factors of palmoplantar epidermoid cysts-HPV infection, ultraviolet exposure, and eccrine duct obstruction.

Presents as asymptomatic, slowly enlarging, painless, superficial localized swellings over the volar aspect of the hand, especially the distal portion of the digits.

Investigations-X-rays, Ultrasonography, FNAC(CT and MRI may be helpful in delineating the anatomy of the soft tissue tumors, although unnecessary to guide the treatment). Histologically, the inclusion epidermoid cysts are lined with stratified squamous epithelium with granular cell layer and are filled with eosinophilic lamellated keratinous material.

Most of the hand dermoid cysts are benign and asymptomatic, and hence surgical intervention is not needed. The surgical treatment is needed for symptomatic cysts causing interference with hand function in which complete excision is done with regional anesthesia under a pneumatic tourniquet.  

Other options:

Option A: Ameloblastoma is a rare, benign tumor that develops most often in the jaw, near the molars. Causes may include injury to the mouth or jaw, infections of the teeth or gums, or inflammation of these same areas.

Option B: Ganglion cysts are fluid filled lumps that most commonly develop along the tendons or joints of the wrists or hands, or ankle or feet. They are round, small and usually painless. Although rare, they can be painful if they press a nerve. In a few cases, the cysts can interfere with joint movements.

Option C: Lipomas are the most common soft tissue tumor in adults. They present as a well-encapsulated mass of mature adipocytes. It usually arises in the subcutis of the proximal extremities and trunk at around 40-60 years of age.

questions.text: Identify the instrument commonly used in obstetrics?
questions.solution:
Episiotomy scissor

The angulation in the scissor is to prevent extension of pelvic tear into the anal margins and obstetretic anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tear.

Structures cut in episiotomy:

  • Vaginal mucosa
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, levator ani muscles.
  • Internal pudendal blood vessels
  • Subcutaneous tissue and perineal skin

questions.text: On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicate:
questions.solution:
On examination of the chest wall, the presence of thrills indicates a palpable murmur. Thrills are the palpable vibrations produced by turbulent blood flow causing murmurs.

Palpable S3 and S4 cause a double thrust in the apical impulse.

Palpable right ventricular systole is known as heave which is felt in the left parasternal area.

questions.text: A woman with AUB-E, who was unresponsive to medical management, underwent a hysteroscopic ablation. Which of the following is false about this procedure?
questions.solution:
Fertility is not preserved with ablative procedures, because the endometrium and superficial myometrium are destroyed.

In ablative procedures, the uterus is preserved, and hysterectomy is avoided. The endometrium along with 2-3mm of superficial myometrium is destroyed.

Various methods of endometrial ablation include:

  • Hysteroscopic endometrial ablation
  • Transcervical endometrial resection (TCRE) - now replaced by bipolar electrode called Versapoint
  • Radiofrequency induced thermal ablation (RITEA)
  • Microwave ablation
  • NovaSure - impedance-controlled endometrial ablation
  • Bilateral uterine artery embolization
  • Uterine tamponade

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops fetalis is caused by ________.
questions.solution:
Both alpha-thalassemia and parvovirus B19 infection cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. 

Hydrops fetalis refers to the abnormal fluid collections in fetal soft tissues and serous cavities. Edema, signs of heart failure, and profound intra-uterine anemia are the presenting features in the fetus. Other clinical features include marked hepatosplenomegaly, retardation in brain growth, hydrocephaly, urogenital and cardiovascular deformities, and extramedullary erythropoiesis.

Non-immune hydrops fetalis (NIHF) comprises the subgroup of cases not caused by red cell alloimmunization (e.g., Rh(D), Kell).

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with no comorbidities presented with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no other illnesses and she says these episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold climates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the history of no previous illness is most likely of primary Raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's phenomenon:

  • Episodic digital ischemia due to the vasospasm of digital arteries.
  • Cold exposure or emotional stress can trigger it.
  • The blanching/ischemic phase of the phenomenon with pallor/cyanosis is often accompanied by numbness and paraesthesia.
  • Capillaries and venules dilate and cyanosis results from the deoxygenated blood that is present in these vessels.
  • Color changes are usually well-demarcated and are confined to the fingers or toes.
  • In the rewarming phase, digital vasospasm resolves and blood flows into the dilated arterioles and capillaries increase dramatically causing reactive hyperemia which imparts bright red color to the digits.
  • Some may experience only pallor cyanosis while others experience both pallor and cyanosis.

Types of Raynaud's:
     1.Primary/idiopathic 

     2. Secondary associated with other diseases like: 

  • Collagen vascular diseases: scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, dermatomyositis, polymyositis
  • Arterial occlusive diseases: atherosclerosis of the extremities, thromboangiitis
    obliterans, acute arterial occlusion
  • Neurologic disorders: intervertebral disk disease, syringomyelia
  • Blood dyscrasias: cold agglutinins, cryoglobulinemia, cryofibrinogenemia,
  • Trauma: vibration injury, electric shock, cold injury, typing, piano playing
  • Drugs and toxins: ergot derivatives, methysergide, β-adrenergic receptor
    blockers

Management:

  • Reassurance, warm clothing, and avoiding cold exposures.
    exposure.
  • Reduce or abstain from smoking and reduce stress levels.
  • Drug treatments such as CCB's(nifedipine, amlodipine), alpha 1 blockers ( prazosin) are used only for advanced cases.
  • In secondary Raynauds's Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors like sildenafil, tadalafil may improve symptoms.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child presents with Hb 6.3g/dL with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Peripheral smear shows a hypochromic microcytic picture with normal leukocytes and platelets. Which of the following tests can be used to screen for and also diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusions, low hemoglobin, and a hypochromic microcytic picture in the smear suggests thalassemia. Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to screen for and also diagnose this condition.

Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to the precipitation of the excess (unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains.

Clinical features seen in thalassemia are:

  • Anemia
  • Jaundice and pigment gallstones
  • Thalassemic facies including features such as maxilla hyperplasia, flat nasal bridge, and frontal bossing
  • Growth impairment
  • Splenomegaly
  • Endocrine abnormalities including hypogonadism, hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus
  • Heart failure and arrhythmias

Repeated blood transfusions are the mainstay of management.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A middle-aged retroviral positive patient presents with a productive cough associated with blood-stained sputum, evening rise in temperature, and weight loss for 3 weeks. His chest radiograph is shown in the image below.  What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is pulmonary tuberculosis.

Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients present with symptoms such as malaise, anorexia, fever, evening rise in temperatures, night sweats, weight loss, cough with expectoration, and hemoptysis. The incidence of this disease is higher in patients who have been diagnosed with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

On chest radiographs, these patients exhibit upper lobe consolidation with hilar lymphadenopathy.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

questions.text: Which among the following Human Papilloma Virus serotypes is commonly associated with carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
Human papilloma virus serotypes 16 and 18 are commonly associated with carcinoma cervix.

questions.text: Which of the following animal is not a known reservoir for the monkeypox virus?
questions.solution:
Lizards are not a known reservoir for the monkeypox virus.

Monkeypox is a zoonotic disease caused by a DNA virus (Orthopoxvirus genus of the Poxviridae family). The disease is self-limiting with signs and symptoms lasting between 2-4 weeks. Although the disease has commonly affected West and central Africa, WHO declared it a public health emergency of international concern on 23rd July 2022 amid its outbreak in over 70 countries. India has currently reported 4 cases with the 1st case detected in Kerala.

Transmission 

The disease is transmitted via direct contact with respiratory secretions, blood, body fluids, and skin or mucosal lesions of infected animals or humans. 

Individuals at risk

  • Children <8 years of age
  • Immunocompromised individuals
  • Pregnant and lactating women
  • Men having sex with men 

Clinical features

Incubation period: 6-13 days

1) Invasive period (0-5 days): 

  • Lymphadenopathy 
  • Fever
  • Headache 
  • Myalgia and asthenia

2) Skin eruption (1-3 days within the occurrence of fever):

  • Centrifugal rashes
  • Sequence of rash formation: macule→papules→vesicles→pustules→crusts
  • Site of distribution: face> palms and soles> oral mucous membranes> genitalia> conjunctiva> cornea

Complications include secondary infections, bronchopneumonia, sepsis, encephalitis and loss of vision (corneal involvement).

Since this is a novel disease, studies are being conducted on the natural history of this disease. Currently, known animal reservoirs for this virus are:

  • Squirrels
  • Rats and other rodents such as gerbils
  • Monkeys and other primates
  • Prairie dogs

questions.text: A young primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. On examination, the cervical os is closed and uterine size is normal. The gestational sac is visible on ultrasound. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of threatened abortion. 

Threatened abortion is defined as bleeding through a closed cervical os in the first 20 weeks of pregnancy, with a live fetus.

The patient presents with a bloody vaginal discharge or bleeding through a closed cervical os. On ultrasound, the gestational sac can be visible. In about two-thirds of the cases, pregnancy continues beyond 28 weeks.

Treatment:

  • Bed rest
  • Analgesics if there is pain
  • Progesterone has been shown to improve outcomes in certain patients

questions.text: The Bone scan in multiple myeloma shows _____
questions.solution:
The Bone scan in multiple myeloma shows cold spot, as there is no compensatory osteoblastic activity.

Multiple myelomas are the most common primary malignant bone neoplasm in adults arising from red marrow due to the monoclonal proliferation of the plasma cells.

Related Pearl: Bone scan findings

Causes of a hot spot

Causes of a cold spot

Osteomyelitis

Bone tumors and metastases

Fibrous dysplasia

Trauma (fracture healing)

Avascular necrosis

Perthes disease

Paget’s disease

Hyperparathyroidism

Multiple myeloma

Fibrous cortical defect

Pseudoarthrosis

questions.text: Transplant of an organ/tissue from mother to child is an example of:
questions.solution:
Transplant of an organ/tissue from a mother to a child is an example of an allograft.

An allograft is a transplant of cells/tissues/organs from a genetically non-identical donor of the same species.

Isograft  is the transfer of cells/tissues/organs are transplanted from a donor to a genetically identical recipient. (monozygotic twins)

Xenograft is tissue transfer from a donor of one species to a recipient of another species. It is also known as heterograft

Autograft is the transfer of tissue from one location to another location on the same patient.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows a manual vacuum aspiration (MVA) syringe.

Manual vacuum aspiration can be safely done up to 12 weeks of gestation. However, WHO recommends it as the procedure of choice for MTP only up to 10 weeks of gestation. 

The indications of this procedure are given as follows:

  • Medical termination of pregnancy
  • Incomplete abortion or missed abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Endometrial aspiration

Other options: 

Karman's cannula: Suction and evacuation is done using a Karman's cannula attached to an automated suction apparatus. 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula is used in hysterosalpingography.

The below image shows a menstrual regulation syringe.Menstrual regulation involves aspiration of the contents of the endometrial cavity within 14 days of a missed period in a woman with previously normal cycles.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated multiple long bone fractures. On examination, there is the presence of blue sclera and dental abnormalities. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated multiple bone fractures, blue sclera, and dental abnormalities are suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta.

Osteogenesis imperfecta(or brittle bone disease) is a connective tissue disorder that occurs due to abnormal type 1 collagen production. It occurs most commonly due to mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. These mutations lead to the replacement of glycine amino acid with another amino acid resulting in an abnormal triple helix of collagen. This results in the abnormal formation of type 1 collagen.

The main features are joints that are vulnerable to fracture (joint laxity), scleral alterations(blue sclera), dentinogenesis imperfecta, and deafness. Multiple bone fractures are a consequence of bone fragility. Bowing of the long bones, wormian bones, and multiple diaphyseal fractures of long bones with various stages are the common radiological findings that are observed. Management comprises the use of bisphosphonates, along with physiotherapy and walking aids.

The images below show blue sclera and wormian bones in osteogenesis imperfecta:

Other options:

Option A: Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant skeletal dysplasia with disproportionately short limbs, sleep apnea, and kyphoscoliosis. Facial features include button nose, frontal bossing, macrocephaly, etc. 

The images below show the features of achondroplasia:

(a) Prominent forehead and body asymmetry, (b) a low nasal bridge, (c) trident hands, (d) scoliosis 

Option C: Cretinism occurs due to iodine deficiency. Its clinical features are deaf-mutism, squint, mental retardation, and spastic or rigid neuromotor disorder. 

Option D: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder. The affected persons will be tall with long limbs and digits. Spontaneous pneumothorax, aortic dissection, and lens dislocation are also seen. An early diastolic murmur is heard on auscultation.

Related Pearl: Subtypes of Osteogenesis imperfecta

Subtypes

Clinical features

Subtype I-

Decreased synthesis of pro-α1(1) chain

Abnormal pro-α1(1) or pro-α2(1) chains

 

Inheritance- 

Autosomal dominant

Postnatal fractures

blue sclera

Normal stature

Skeletal fragility

Dentinogenesis imperfecta

Hearing impairment

Joint laxity

 

Prognosis- 

Compatible with survival

Subtype II- 

Abnormally short pro-α1(1) chain Unstable triple helix Abnormal or insufficient pro-α2(1)

 

Inheritance-

Death in utero or within days of birth

Skeletal deformity with excessive fragility and multiple fractures

Blue sclera

 

Prognosis- 

Perinatal lethal

Subtype III-

Impaired formation of triple helix

 

Inheritance- 

Autosomal dominant (75%) Autosomal recessive (25%)

Growth retardation

Multiple fractures

Progressive kyphoscoliosis

Blue sclera at birth that become white

Hearing impairment

Dentinogenesis imperfecta

 

Prognosis-

Inheritance-

Postnatal fractures

normal sclerae
