questions.text:
The components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) include which of the following:
  1. Glasgow coma scale
  2. Respiratory Rate
  3. Pulse Rate
  4. Systolic BP
  5. Mechanism of Injury
questions.solution:
The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiologic scoring system based on the initial vital signs of a trauma patient.

Revised Trauma Score (RTS) includes :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

The score range is 0–12. A lower score indicates a higher severity of injury. 

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 3 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: Modified Schober’s test is performed in?
questions.solution:
Modified Schober’s test is performed in ankylosing spondylitis to detect reduced flexion of the spine.

The test involves marking two points- 10 cm above and 5cm below the level of the lumbosacral junction of the patient. The patient is then asked to bend forward and the distance between the two points is measured.

This distance normally increases by ≥5 cm. An increase of <4 cm indicates reduced flexion.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD with complaints of infertility. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is a varicocele.

Varicocele is a disease characterized by abnormal dilatation of the veins draining the testis. It is seen in patients with incompetence or absence of valves in the proximal testicular vein.

Patients present with symptoms such as discomfort worsened by standing. On palpation, the varicosities feel like a bag of worms. Mild testicular atrophy may also be seen in patients with long-standing varicocele. Varicoceles are commonly seen in patients with infertility, though the exact mechanism is unclear.

Usually, these patients require no surgical management if there is no significant discomfort. In the case of patients with significant discomfort, percutaneous embolization or surgical ligation of the gonadal veins may be attempted.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with a history of constipation. Clinical examination reveals jaundice and hypotonia. His picture is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above picture, the child shows a protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and edematous facies. Also, the infant has jaundice, constipation, and hypotonia, which suggests a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia: early sign
  • Constipation: usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular: slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory: macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological: macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system: hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence.

questions.text: A young patient was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following is not a 'B symptom' expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pruritus is not a b symptom of Hodgkin's lymphoma. The b symptoms of Hodgkin's lymphoma are persistent fever (>100.4ºF), drenching night sweats, and unexplained weight loss of >10% body weight over the past 6 months.

Hodgkin's lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm characterized by the histological presence of Reed Sternberg cells on a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells.

The patient commonly presents with palpable, firm, rubbery, non-tender lymphadenopathy in the cervical or supraclavicular region. Systemic symptoms that are classified as B symptoms are important in the staging of the disease. Hepatosplenomegaly is rarely detected clinically. 

Ann Arbor Staging of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma:

Stage I

Involvement of a single lymph node (I) or of a single extra-lymphatic organ or site (IE)

Stage II

Involvement of 2 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (II) or localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site and 1 or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm (IIE)

Stage III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm (III), which may be accompanied by

involvement of the spleen (IIIS) or

by localized involvement of an extra-lymphatic organ or site (IIIE) or

both (IIISE)

Stage IV

Diffuse or disseminated involvement of 1 or more

extra-lymphatic organs or tissues with or without

associated lymph node involvement
 

B symptoms

  • The presence of fever >38°C (100.4°F) for 3 consecutive days
  • Drenching night sweats
  • Unexplained loss of >10% of body weight in the 6 months

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman presents with episodes of a sudden sensation of intense heat involving the face and upper chest which rapidly spreads across the entire body. The episodes last about 2-4 minutes and are associated with profuse sweating, palpitations, and anxiety. What is the most effective treatment for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vasomotor symptoms (hot flushes) in a postmenopausal woman. Estrogen therapy is found to be the most effective to treat it.

Hot flushes are episodes of vasodilation affecting the face and the neck. The episode lasts for 2–5 min each. These are followed by severe sweating, palpitations, anxiety, and anginal pains may be felt. Multiple episodes occur during the day, but are more severe at night and can disturb sleep. Sometimes they can be preceded by headaches.

Hormone therapy in postmenopausal women is only indicated for the treatment of:

  • vasomotor symptoms
  • osteoporosis (prevention and treatment)
  • vaginal atrophy
  • urethral syndrome
  • dyspareunia

Estrogen can be given as oral estrogen formulations, transdermal patches, topical gel, or intravaginal formulations. For Dyspareunia, urethral syndrome, and senile vaginitis local estrogen cream is preferred over oral therapy. Short-term therapy is recommended for vasomotor symptoms whereas osteoporosis requires long-term therapy. Estrogen should be given in the smallest effective dose for the shortest duration possible. 

 Other treatments: 

Hormonal Non-Hormonal Non-prescriptive

Estrogen therapy (Most effective)

Progestin

Combination preparations

Tibolone

Clonidine 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (like Fluoxetine)

selective norepinephrine- reuptake inhibitor(like desvenlafaxine)

Gabapentin

Vitamin E

Soya 

Isoflavones

Contraindications of HRT:

  • Undiagnosed abnormal genital bleeding
  • Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
  • Known or suspected estrogen-dependent neoplasia
  • Active or prior venous thromboembolism
  • Active or recent (e.g., within the past year) arterial thromboembolic disease
  • Liver dysfunction or gall bladder disease
  • Known hypersensitivity to the ingredients of the estrogen preparation
  • Known or suspected pregnancy
  • Uterine fibroids as these may enlarge in size.

For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add micronized progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur after 6 months of estrogen therapy. For women without uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.

questions.text: You were posted as a medical officer in a Kala-azar endemic area. There was a rise in the number of insects shown in the given image below. Identify the insect:
questions.solution:
The image given is that of a sandfly (Phlebotomus), which is the vector for Kala-azar.

Sandflies are generally small insects, light or dark brown in color. They are smaller than mosquitoes. Their body and wings are densely clothed with hair. Their wings are up-right and lanceolate in shape and their legs are longer compared with the size of the body. They hop about and do not fly much. The species of sandfly responsible for transmitting the disease kala-azar is Phlebotomus argentipes. 

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by various species of the genus Leishmania. It can present as visceral leishmaniasis, cutaneous leishmaniasis, ad mucosal leishmaniasis. Clinical features of the visceral form include moderate to high-grade fever with chills and rigors, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. 

The gold standard test for the diagnosis is the demonstration of amastigotes in the smears of tissue aspirates. Another commonly used test is the detection of antibodies to a recombinant antigen called rK39 by a rapid immunochromatographic test. In immunocompromised individuals, parasites can be isolated from the buffy coat. Amphotericin B is the first-line drug used in India. 

Other diseases transmitted by sandflies include sandfly fever and oriental sore.

For the reduction of sandflies, a  single application of DDT (dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane) or lindane has been found effective. 

Other options:

Option A: Tsetse flies or glossinae are the blood-sucking flies that resemble the common houseflies. They are yellow or dark-brown in color. When folded, their wings overlap each other like the blade of a scissor. They have a non-retractile proboscis which is rigid and adapted for piercing the skin and sucking the blood. They are vectors for trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness and are only found in regions in Africa.

 

Option C- Rat flea is the vector for plague and typhus. They are wingless, their head is conical in shape, and is directly attached to the thorax without a neck. The head has piercing mouth parts that are conspicuous and project downward for sucking blood. They have 3 pairs of legs attached to the thorax. 

Option D: Black flies are small robust flies. They are black short stout legs, large broad wings, and a short proboscis to suck blood. They are the vectors of onchocerciasis in Africa, Mexico, Central, and South America.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child develops hematuria after 4 days of severe diarrhea. Peripheral smear shows fragmented RBCs and thrombocytopenia. Ultrasound reveals the enlargement of both kidneys. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal vein thrombosis secondary to dehydration.

Hematuria in children following diarrhea can be due to the following:

  Hemolytic uremic syndrome Renal vein thrombosis
Onset 5-10 days after diarrhea Depends on severity of dehydration
 Renal failure Present Present
Hematuria + +
Peripheral smear  fragmented RBCs + +
Platelets Decreased Decreased
USG kidney Normal Enlarged due to congestion by renal vein thrombosis (bilateral in 67% cases)

Henoch-Schonlein purpura would present 1-3 weeks after an upper respiratory infection. It causes hematuria, non-blanching rash over the buttocks, and abdominal pain.

questions.text: Pre-exposure prophylaxis for rabies is given on _______
questions.solution: Pre-exposure prophylaxis is given for rabies on Days 0, 7, 21, or 28.

questions.text: A 25 year old man presents to the clinic with hair loss. He gives a history of being on a highly restrictive diet (one that does not meet his daily protein requirements) and sudden weight loss for the last 4 months. What is the clinical diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
This male most probably has telogen efflivium. This male had sudden weight loss with protein deficit, which could have acted as a trigger for this condition.

Telogen effluvium describes an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.

Acute telogen effluvium is an acute-onset scalp hair loss that occurs 2–3 months after a triggering event such as high fever, surgical trauma, sudden weight loss/starvation or haemorrhage.

Chronic diffuse telogen hair loss refers to telogen hair shedding persisting for longer than 6 months. Causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss are thyroid disorders, profound iron deficiency anaemia, acroder­matitis enteropathica, and malnutrition. Both hyper- and hypo­thyroidism (including drug-induced hypothyroidism) may cause a diffuse telogen hair loss.

Telogen gravidarum refers to telogen hair loss seen 2–3 months after childbirth.

Option A: Alopecia areata is a common, chronic, inflammatory disease that causes non‐scarring hair loss. Alopecia areata is associated with several autoimmune diseases including thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo and psoriasis.

Option B: Androgenetic alopecia is a permanent hair loss from the scalp, causing baldness, and have a common genetic cause. Hair loss typically occurs on the top and front of the head. It occurs progressively, unlike seen here. 

Option D: Anagen effluvium is a type of alopecia, which is the sudden loss of anagen (actively growing) hair, usually occuring post chemotherapy.

questions.text: Name the incision shown in this image.
questions.solution:
The image shows Weber–Ferguson incision which is used to access the floor of the maxillary sinus in the case of maxillary carcinoma.

Incisions for modified radical neck dissection (MRND)

Blair’s Incision

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding population pyramids:

choices.text: They shows the distribution of ages across a population.
They can be used to compare the male and female population.
Youngest of the population is represented at the bottom.
Narrow base and wide middle is typical of developing countries.

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding population pyramids is option D. Population pyramids of developed countries typically have a narrow base and wide middle, whereas those of developing countries have a broad base and a tapering top. 

A population pyramid is a graphical representation of the age and sex of the population, and therefore, it is also called an age and sex pyramid.

The youngest of the population is represented at the bottom and the oldest at the top of the pyramid.

Besides showing the distribution of ages across a population, the pyramid is divided across the center to separate the male and female members of the population; therefore, they can be used to compare the difference between the male and female populations of a given area.

It also shows the number of dependents in the population at any given time.

Related Pearl: Population Pyramid

  • The age or population pyramid is used to represent the age/sex structure of a population.
  • Below is the age pyramid of India (2017).
  • The age pyramid of India has a broad base and a tapering top, as it is with most developing countries.
  • As a nation develops the lower portion of the pyramid will start constricting and the upper portion will start increasing. 
  • Developed countries usually will have a bulge in the middle with a narrow base, as shown below in the age pyramid of Switzerland.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness. There is a history of similar complaints in the family members. They recently consumed food prepared from the contaminated grains shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing wheat grains infested with blackish fungal mass are suggestive of ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20 percent saltwater. Floatation and handpicking can also be used for the removal.

Disease   Food Substance  Toxic Principle  Clinical features
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus /Khesari dal  BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine 

Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Acute - Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness

Chronic - Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids 

Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Inspiratory coarse crackles are not a feature of interstitial lung disease. Auscultating a patient with ILD will reveal bilateral basal inspiratory fine crackles, also called velcro crackles.

ILD refers to the remodelling of interstitial space, the region between the epithelium and endothelium. Patients with interstitial lung disease usually present with a non-productive cough and breathlessness on exertion. 

Clubbing may be seen on examination, especially in advanced cases. DLCO (diffusion capacity of lung) is decreased. Fever and wheezing are usually not seen in patients of ILD.

questions.text:
Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhoea with their respective lab findings.
Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A.

Condition Lab markers 
1. Sheehan's syndrome C. Low LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
2. Premature Ovarian failure D. High LH, High FSH, Low estradiol
3. PCOS B. High LH, Low FSH, Low estradiol
4. Asherman's syndrome A. Normal FSH, Normal LH, Normal estradiol

Secondary amenorrhoea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.

Premature Ovarian failure or premature menopause is the development of menopause before the age of 40 years. It is diagnosed when at least 2 serum FSH levels are elevated (>40 mIU/l) when measured at least 1 month apart in a woman <40 years. The other findings consistent with POF include low estradiol and an elevated FSH/LH ratio.

Asherman's syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of large areas of the endometrium, most commonly as a result of trauma to the endometrium following pregnancy-related curettages. Oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion, and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae. The laboratory investigations and hormonal assays are generally normal in isolated cases of uterine synechiae. Diagnosis is generally established using hysteroscopy. Moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome. Treatment is by hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

PCOS is a multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrone(E1) levels are elevated but estradiol level in PCOS is low in comparison to Estrone (E1). 

Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. Affected women may present with panhypopituitarism and may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure. The most prominent symptoms are lactation failure (due to the deficiency of prolactin) and postpartum amenorrhea (due to the deficiency of gonadotropins).

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: The critical obstetric conjugate for trial of labor is ______.
questions.solution:
The clinically important obstetric conjugate is the shortest distance between the sacral promontory and the symphysis pubis.

Normally, this measures 10 cm or more, but unfortunately, it cannot be measured directly by the examiner's fingers. For clinical purposes, the obstetrical conjugate is estimated indirectly by subtracting 1.5–2 cm from the diagonal conjugate, which is determined by measuring the lowest margin of the symphysis to the sacral promontory.

The red line marked 4 is the obstetric conjugate. The red line marked 5 is the pelvic outlet.

questions.text: Type of Suturing shown below is:
questions.solution:
Interrupted Sutures: Each Suture should reach into the depths of the wound and be placed at right angles to the axis of the wound.

Option B: In mattress Suture the initial suture is inserted as for an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in picture.

Option C: Continuous Suture: For a continuous Suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Option D: Subcuticular Sutures: Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

questions.text: A child is brought to the emergency department with swelling and pain over the proximal forearm. The mother claims that the child fell on an outstretched hand while playing with friends. The radiograph shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph shows a fracture of the proximal ulna along with a dislocation of the head of the radius. This type of injury is termed a Monteggia fracture.

Patients present with symptoms such as swelling and pain in the proximal forearm region. The mechanism of injury in such a fracture is usually a fall on an outstretched hand or a direct injury to the back of the upper forearm.

Monteggia fracture is an unstable fracture and is usually managed surgically with open reduction and internal fixation.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar displacement.

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of the ulnar bone.

questions.text: A young female patient is being evaluated for recurrent first-trimester pregnancy loss. On investigation, the activated partial thromboplastin time was prolonged, and the anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibody was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA). 

APLA is characterized by recurrent thrombosis due to the formation of autoantibodies. It generally affects women. APLA should be considered in those under the age of 55 with recurrent thrombosis. The presence of at least one clinical and laboratory criterion is required for diagnosis. 

Clinical criteria: 

  • Vascular thrombosis with one or more episodes of thrombosis (arterial, venous, or small vessel) in any organ
  • Pregnancy morbidity
    1. With the unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus after 10 weeks
    2. Premature birth of a morphologically normal fetus before 34th week due to preeclampsia, eclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    3. Three or more unexplained spontaneous abortions before the 10th week.

Laboratory criteria: 

  • Positive lupus anticoagulant (LA)
  • Positive anticardiolipin (aCL)
  • Positive anti-beta2GPI antibodies.

Treatment involves lifelong warfarin therapy titrated to a goal INR of 2.5-3.5. Aspirin may also be added at a dose of 80 mg. 

Other options: 

Option B - Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute condition characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation in response to activation of the coagulation cascade. It is not associated with LA. In addition, this patient has a chronic history of recurrent DVT and pregnancy loss. Elevated levels of fibrin degradation products are sensitive for diagnosing DIC

Option C - Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a form of systemic hypercoagulability that arises from a paraneoplastic syndrome because of procoagulant factors. There would be multiple venous thromboses that appear, disappear, and reappear in another location. 

Option D - Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia. It is a bleeding disorder and is not characterized by recurrent thrombosis. It is associated with recurrent bleeding into soft tissues, joints (hemarthrosis), and muscles as a result of trauma or spontaneous mechanism. Lab values show prolonged aPTT.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents at 33 weeks gestation with intermittent uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 80% effaced and 2.5cm dilated. To allow fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). 

  • Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. 
  • Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Preterm labor is the onset of labor before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies, and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labor to look for cervical incompetence. 

It is diagnosed by:

  • Uterus - regular contractions at least one in every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes or 8 contractions in 60 min with/without pain. 
  • Cervix - dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% 
  • TVS - length of cervix <2.5 cm and funneling of the internal os >1 cm
  • Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding PV

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

Management includes short-term therapy with tocolytics, given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labor for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary center (centers with NICU). The tocolytics include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female underwent screening mammography. Which of the following findings in her mammogram is least suggestive of a malignancy?
questions.solution:
Microcalcification (<0.5 mm in diameter) in mammography is suggestive of malignancy. Macrocalcification is seen in benign breast disorders.

Table: Mammographic appearance of benign and malignant masses  

  Benign Malignant
Opacity
  • Low density
  • Homogenous
  • Smooth margin
  • Thin halo
  • High density
  • Not homogenous
  • Ill-defined margin, irregular stellate spiculated margin, comet tail
  • Wide halo
Calcification Macrocalcification (>0.5 mm) Microcalcification (<0.5 mm)
Breast parenchyma Normal Architectural distortion
Nipple/areola Normal Retraction
Skin Normal Thickening
Cooper ligaments Normal

Thickening, increase in number
Ducts Normal Focal dilatation
Subcutaneous and mammary space Normal Obliteration

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented with chest pain that was unrelated to physical exertion. ECG showed ST-segment elevation. Intracoronary acetylcholine provocation testing revealed a transient spasm of the right coronary artery. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above scenario in which rest pain is associated with ST-segment elevation and transient coronary vasospasm is suggestive of Prinzmetal's angina. The drug of choice is a calcium channel blocker.

Prinzmetal variant angina (PVA) is a clinical syndrome in which chest pain occurs without the usual precipitating factors. It usually results from coronary vasoconstriction (vasospasm) and tends to involve the right coronary artery.

It is a supply ischemia and usually causes transmural ischemia (subendocardial in classic angina pectoris).

It often affects women under 50 years of age. It characteristically occurs in the early morning, awakening patients from sleep, and may be associated with arrhythmias or conduction defects.

The clinical diagnosis of PVA is made by the detection of transient ST-segment elevation with rest pain. Coronary angiography demonstrates transient coronary spasm which is the diagnostic hallmark of PVA.

Nitrates and calcium channel blockers both can be used in alleviating symptoms in Prinzmetal's angina. However due to the development of nitrate tolerance in some individuals, they are less preferred and calcium channel blockers such as verapamil, diltiazem are used as first-line agents.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. He is bleeding profusely and his blood pressure is 90/64 mmHg and a pulse rate of 130 per minute. 4 units of packed RBCs is immediately transfused. All of the following complications can occur in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The complication of massive transfusion includes hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

Citrate is used as an anticoagulant in stored blood. Rapid administration of large amounts of stored blood during massive blood transfusion (MBT) can lead to the chelation of calcium and magnesium ions by citrate, resulting in hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.

The lethal triad of massive transfusion includes acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy. Other complications which can be seen in massive transfusion are:

  • Hypocalcaemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia

Related Pearl: Complications of massive transfusion: The concept behind It

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis/Acidosis
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperkalemia

Understanding the concept:

  1. Hypothermia: Blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C, and rapid transfusion of large quantities will lead to hypothermia.
  2. Coagulopathy: MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy, whereas massive hemorrhage causes a consumptive coagulopathy. However, the incidence of coagulopathy can be minimized by the infusion of fresh frozen plasma, platelets, and RBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio. 
  3. Alkalosis: As citrate is metabolized to bicarbonate, patients who require MT frequently develop a metabolic alkalosis. 
  4. Acidosis: Due to tissue hypoperfusion
  5. Hyperkalemia & late Hypokalemia: Initially, the patient develops hyperkalemia on massive transfusion. Later, red blood cells begin active metabolism and intracellular potassium uptake. This increased uptake along with metabolic alkalosis (resulting from citrate administration), lowers the serum potassium.
  6. Hypocalcemia: Binding of calcium to citrate (which is used in the anticoagulation of the stored blood).
  7. Hypomagnesemia: Binding of magnesium to citrate

questions.text:
The growth parameters of an 18-month-old girl baby were charted as shown in the image below. This child can be classified to have ____.

ICDS - Integrated child development scheme
questions.solution:
From the World Health Organization (WHO) growth chart  (length for age), the child falls below -3SD and is classified to have chronic malnutrition/ severe stunting.

Low height for age (height for age < -2SD) in children indicates chronic malnutrition and stunting. 

Classification of nutritional status depending on the anthropometry (height/length for age): 

Classification Criteria
Moderate stunting (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –2 SD and > –3 SD
Severe stunting (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/length-for-age < –3 SD

The nutritional status of a child is assessed in terms of anthropometry:

The World Health Organization (WHO) has established international standards for normal child growth from birth to 5 years of age. The normalization of the anthropometric measures is done in terms of z-scores (standard deviation scores). The anthropometric indicators are marked in a growth chart which is compared with a reference curve.

The anthropometric measures used are weight for age, height for age, weight for height, BMI, and mid-upper arm circumference.

  • Low weight-for-height, or wasting, indicates acute malnutrition. It is also mentioned as wasting.
  • High weight-for-height indicates overweight.
  • Low height-for-age, or stunting, indicates chronic malnutrition. This is the best indicator of long-term nutritional status in the pediatric population. 
  • Low weight-for-age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition. It does not differentiate between wasting and stunting. Hence, it has limited clinical significance.

Related Pearl: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD

SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Liddle's syndrome is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension.

It is an autosomal dominant condition due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene. This gene codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. This leads to increased sodium retention and results in a state of pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. The following findings are seen:

  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Normal-low aldosterone
  • Low renin 

Treatment is with diuretics that directly block the ENaC channels, like amiloride and triamterene. Spironolactone is not effective as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.

Other options:

Option A- Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). There is extracellular fluid volume depletion with low or normal blood pressure. It is characterized by metabolic alkalosis, decreased potassium and chloride, and, occasionally, hypomagnesemia. 

Option C- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide-sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with low blood pressure.

Option D- Gordon syndrome is a state of pseudohypoaldosteronism. It is characterized by hypertension, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and low-normal plasma renin activity and aldosterone concentrations.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A person had an accidental spillover of hot liquid. On examination, there were multiple fluid-filled blisters, which when ruptured have an erythematous base. They are extremely painful and blanch to touch. Which layer is involved in blister formation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of superficial partial-thickness burns. The papillary dermis is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn.

  • First degree: Involves only epidermis, with pain and redness
  • Second degree: Involves epidermis and some part of dermis (also known as partial thickness burns). Further divided into:
    • Superficial second degree or superficial partial thickness involves upper part of dermis (papillary) - pain, blisters, severe swelling.
    • Deep second degree or deep partial thickness - extends up to reticular layer of dermis; appear more pale and mottled, do not blanch to touch, but remain painful to pinprick.
  • Third degree or full thickness burns - involves full thickness of dermis and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Fourth degree burns - involves deep structures such as muscle, bone and brain.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below.  Which of the following statements about this method is false?

choices.text: Safety and thermal protection provided by this method is comparable to incubators
Should be performed only by the mother

questions.solution:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is at least equivalent to incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

Eligibiilty criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birthweight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birthweight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birthweight 1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birthweight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

questions.text: The vector shown in the following image is responsible for the transmission of which of the following diseases
questions.solution:
The image depicts an Aedes mosquito. This vector is responsible for the transmission of the zika virus disease.

The mosquitoes belonging to the genus Aedes can be easily distinguished by their characteristic white stripes on a black body appearance. Due to these stripes, they are also sometimes referred to as tiger mosquitoes.

The zika virus disease is caused by the zika virus which belongs to the genus flavivirus. This virus is transmitted through the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito, namely Aedes aegypti.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs. 

 

 

  • Culex mosquito, they keep their bodies horizontal while feeding:

 

  • Anopheles mosquito as seen in the image below, they tend to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high:

 

  • Aedes mosquito (aegypti), as seen in the image below, their bodies are striped:

questions.text: In which of the following situations is ventouse delivery contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ventouse delivery is contraindicated in preterm babies as it increases the risk of scalp avulsion or sub-aponeurotic haemorrhage.

Contraindications of vacuum delivery:

  • Any presentation other than vertex (such as face/breech)
  • Preterm fetus (less than 34 weeks)
  • Suspected fetal coagulation disorder
  • Fetal macrosomia (more than 4 kg estimated weight)

A vacuum extractor is an instrument used in operative vaginal delivery by creating a vacuum between it and the fetal scalp. 

The instrument consists of 

  • Suction cup
  • Vacuum generator
  • Traction tubing device.

The suction cup is placed on the fetal head at a point near the occiput called the flexion point, which is an imaginary point on the sagittal suture, located about 6 cm from the centre of the anterior fontanel or about 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanel. The flexion point is closer to the posterior fontanel as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Vacuum delivery- indications and contraindications

Indications of ventouse:    

Therapeutic-

  • Fetal distress in second stage
  • Maternal distress in second stage
  • Prolonged second stage
  • Deep transverse arrest and persistent occipitoposterior
  • High vacuum for second twin

Prophylactic-

  • Preeclampsia
  • VBAC
  • Cardiac defects
  • Anemia

Contraindications of ventouse:     

  • Preterm head
  • Face presentation         
  • Fetal coagulopathy
  • Fetal blood sampling

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the methods of MTP?

choices.text: Pain is more in medical methods of abortion
Incomplete abortion is more common in medical methods
Bleeding is prolonged in surgical methods
Failure rate is low in surgical methods of abortion

questions.solution:
Bleeding is prolonged and unpredictable in medical methods of abortion.

Comparison of drawbacks of medical and surgical methods of MTP:

Factor Medical methods Surgical methods
Invasiveness Usually not invasive Invasive
Pain More Less
Vaginal bleeding Prolonged, unpredictable Light, predictable
Incomplete abortion More common Uncommon
Failure rate 2-5% 1%
Severe bleeding 0.1% 0.1%
Infection rate Low Low
Anesthesia Usually not given Always given
Time involved  Multiple visits for follow-up  Usually one visit
No follow-ups required

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought into the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There is no history of fever, night sweats, and weight loss. MRI  was done and the ​image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This HIV patient with seizures and MRI showing a solitary rim-enhancing lesion in the left posterior frontal lobe most likely has cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis:

  • It is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL.
  • It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Diagnosis:

MRI: Usually multiple lesions in multiple locations, however, in some cases a single lesion may be present. These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis and hence show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Surrounding edema is usually present.

Treatment: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 

Prophylaxis: Primary prophylaxis with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given to patients with low CD4+ T cell count. The same regimen also offers primary protection against P. jirovecii. 

Other conditions with single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include primary CNS lymphoma (usually solitary, solid and subependymal lesion) and, less commonly, TB or fungal or bacterial abscesses.

Cryptococcus neoformans is the most common cause of meningitis in HIV patients. It does not cause ring-enhancing lesions

Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumour of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms. MRI would show multifocal, asymmetric periventricular and subcortical involvement.

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker presents with a history of intermittent crampy lower abdominal pain and episodic diarrhea that has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks. Examination revealed tenderness in the right iliac fossa and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this given case scenario is Crohn's disease.

This patient's history is suggestive of ileocolitis which commonly presents as recurrent episodes of right lower quadrant pain and diarrhea. The most common site of inflammation in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, smoking is seen to have a protective effect in ulcerative colitis.

Other options-

Option B- Diverticulitis occurs in the sigmoid colon, therefore they have left-sided signs and symptoms. 

Option D- Irritable bowel syndrome is not characterized by bowel inflammation and is a diagnosis by exclusion.

questions.text: The diagnosis from the given chest X-ray is  ________.
questions.solution:
The given X-ray demonstrates “3” sign, which is pathognomic of coarctation of aorta.

  • 3 sign
    • Indentation of aorta at the site of coarctation
    • Pre- and post-stenotic dilatation along the left paramediastinal shadow
  • Other Chest X-ray features in coarctation of aorta
    • Dilated left subclavian artery
    • Dilated ascending aorta
    • Notching of 3rd and 9th ribs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is this instrument contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The image shows Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve. It is contraindicated in obstructed labour.

Piper forceps is a specialized forceps, used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head of the breech (Option A). It can also be used in cases of occipito-posterior position and caesarian delivery (Options B and C). It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the emergency department with a history of excessive crying. On examination, there is abdominal distension and tenderness. A barium enema is done and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in the above infant is intussusception. 

Intussusception is a condition characterized by the invagination of one segment of the bowel into another. It may be ileocolic, colocolic or ileoileal. It is speculated that upper respiratory tract infections causing edema of the Peyer patches is an etiological factor in children.

Infants are commonly brought to the emergency department with complaints of bouts of excessive crying, abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stool.

Ultrasound is the investigation of choice and it shows the target/ doughnut sign. On barium enema, these children demonstrate a characteristic claw sign(shown below).  

Other options:

Option B: Patients with sigmoid volvulus demonstrate the omega sign or the coffee bean sign.

Option C: Duodenal atresia is commonly seen in newborns. Babies usually present with bilious/non-bilious vomiting immediately after birth. A plain X-ray abdomen reveals two foci of gas, one in the stomach and the other in the duodenum called the double bubble sign.

Option D: Intestinal obstruction presents with abdominal pain, distension and constipation. A plain radiograph of the abdomen shows multiple air-fluid levels.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presents with pain around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. Which among the following is the management for the condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the x-ray image showing the sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle, in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma, and the management for this patient would be wide excision.

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone with bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade. The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays are diagnostic showing Codman’s triangle (new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation) and a ‘sunburst’ appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

Other options:

Option A: Curettage is mainly used for the management of giant cell tumors. It is a benign, locally aggressive tumor presenting in the 2nd-4th decade with distal femoral metaphysis or epiphysis as the most common site. Radiographic findings include solitary lytic lesions and soap bubble appearance shown below.

Option B: Radiofrequency ablation is the preferred treatment for osteoid osteoma. It is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone. It is common in men and most commonly occurs in the diaphysis of the femur.

Option D: Intralesional steroids are used in the management of simple bone cysts that occur most commonly in males near the metaphyseal areas. 

Related Pearl: Summary of Bone Tumors

Bone tumor Most common site Age
Simple bone cyst Proximal Humeral Metaphysis <20years
Enchondroma

(Metaphysis of small bones of hand)

Decade

(Exostosis)

BIMODAL
