questions.text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in patients with polycythemia vera?
questions.solution:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

JAK2 mutations can be found in the following neoplasms:

  • Polycythemia vera
  • Essential thrombocythemia
  • Primary myelofibrosis

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria

1 . Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

Or

     Increased red cell mass (RCM)

2 . Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation.

3. Presence of JAK2 mutation

Minor criterion

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text:
A young patient presents with a history of increased urinary frequency, nocturia, and excessive thirst. Her laboratory investigations are given below. Brain MRI shows the absence of a bright spot in the pituitary. Her past medical history includes an episode of viral encephalitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Urine osmolarity <300 mOsm/L
Urine output >50 ml/kg/day
Random blood glucose 150 mg/dl
Antidiuretic hormone level (ADH) Decreased
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the lab results indicating increased urine output with low urine osmolarity and decreased ADH levels suggest a diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus. 

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to a deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. In this patient, it is likely that her prior episode of viral encephalitis has led to the development of DI. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analog. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, a low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

Other options:

Option A: In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. The two can be differentiated by the water deprivation test. (Option A)

Option B - Primary polydipsia would have a bright spot on the brain MRI. Primary polydipsia presents with an excessive thirst that reduces the serum osmolarity. There is a compensatory increase in free water excretion that offsets the increased intake to maintain a normal serum sodium level. 

Option D - Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion would have increased ADH secretion, concentrated urine, and hyponatremia. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

 

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text: Diagnose the respiratory condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is bronchiectasis. The CT scan shows the signet ring sign which is specific for bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis refers to the irreversible dilatation of one or more bronchi, which occurs due to recurrent cycles of infection, inflammation, and tissue damage. Development of the disease requires an infectious insult in combination with impaired bacterial clearance (eg, impaired immune defenses, structural airway defect).

The clinical scenario observed in bronchiectasis is: 

  • Repeated chest infections 
  • Presence of large amounts of yellow sputum 
  • Non-smoker 

Bronchiectasis is commonly associated with

  • Kartagener syndrome
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.

Radiological findings - Chest X-ray shows tram track appearance due to the dilated airways. 

CT findings include:

  • Tram track appearance
  • Signet ring sign
  • Lack of bronchial tapering
  • Tree-in-bud pattern - It occurs due to the thickening of the dilated airways along with the inspissated secretions.
  • Cysts originating from the bronchial wall (pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis)

Note: High-Resolution CT (HRCT) is the best method for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis. 

Other options:

Option A: Pulmonary tuberculosis is an infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Patients often present with chronic cough and hemoptysis. Low-grade fever, anorexia, and weight loss are the commonly associated symptoms. CT findings of pulmonary tuberculosis are Ghon focus, Ranke complex, nodal calcifications, cavities, and hilar/paratracheal lymphadenopathy.

Option B: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease[COPD], is inflammation-induced destruction of lung parenchyma resulting from cigarette smoke or other pollutants. Patients typically will be smokers with exertional dyspnea, and cough with productive sputum. Lung hyperinflation (emphysema) and airflow obstruction are characteristic of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. 

Option C: Bronchial asthma is an airway hyperresponsiveness disease characterized by reversible airway narrowing and obstruction by mucus plugging. Patients typically present with symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough usually on exposure to triggering agents. CT findings in bronchial asthma are bronchial wall thickening, mucus plugging, decreased lung attenuation, and gas trapping.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl passed 18 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours. She is irritable but is eagerly drinking fluids. What is the next step in the management of this child?

choices.text: Oral rehydration therapy with oral rehydration solution
Intravenous fluids for 2 hours followed by oral fluids

questions.solution:
Oral rehydration therapy is the initial recommendation in managing patients with acute diarrheal illness across all age groups.

The child described in the clinical vignette exhibits features of some dehydration. She can be managed with plan B. According to this recommendation, the child is initially advised 75ml/kg of ORS and then evaluated.

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

Related Pearl: Treatment of dehydration based on severity

Plan A: For no dehydration or minimal dehydration. ORS is administered after each loose stool.

Age Amount 
<2 years 50–100 mL
2-10 years 100–200 mL
>10 years As much fluid as they want

Plan B: For moderate dehydration.

The amount of oral rehydration solution (ORS) to be given is 75 mL/kg body weight (wt × 75).

Plan C: Severe dehydration

Age First, give 30 mL/kg in Followed by 70 mL/kg in Total 100 mL/kg in
Infants (under 12 months) 1 hr 5 hrs  6 hrs
Older 30 min 2½ hrs  3 hrs

Note: Ringer lactate (ideal) or normal saline is used as intravenous fluids.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about De Quervain’s thyroiditis except______

choices.text: Treatment of choice is supportive and NSAIDs
Characterized by painful and enlarged thyroid
Both thyrotoxic and hypothyroid phases can be observed

questions.solution:
De Quervain’s thyroiditis is not autoimmune in origin. It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections.

Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are generally affected three times more often than men.

Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever.

It has three distinct phases: The thyrotoxic phase followed by the hypothyroid phase and the recovery phase.

It is treated with large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids and/or beta-blockers to relieve the observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

questions.text: A child is brought to the outpatient department with the following karyotyping image. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such children?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows 47, XXY abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter syndrome. Gynecomastia and long limbs are seen in this condition.

Klinefelter's syndrome is a sex chromosome abnormality and is the most common cause of infertility and hypogonadism in males.

Other clinical features seen in Klinefelter’s syndrome are: 

  • Tall stature and long limbs
  • Small atrophic testis and small penis
  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production)
  • Gynecomastia
  • Minor developmental and learning disabilities,
  • Higher risk of breast carcinoma and extragonadal germ cell tumors
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus

 

Other options:

Options B and C- Low set ears, prominent occiput, and micrognathia are seen in Edwards syndrome.

Option D- Webbing of the neck and lymphedema are seen in Turner syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following  is not a cardinal movement occurring during labor?
questions.solution:
Asynclitism is not a cardinal movement during labor.

Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder. This causes the fetal head to no longer be in line with the birth canal.

Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labor. However, if severe, this condition is a common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis. 

Asynclitism can be of 2 types:

  • When the sagittal suture lies anteriorly, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism.
  • When the sagittal suture lies posteriorly, the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with miosis, ptosis, and anhydrosis on the left side along with dysphagia, and dysarthria, and frequently falls towards the left side while walking. On examination, he was found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the body and the left side of the face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient having left-sided Horner's syndrome, dysphagia, dysarthria, ataxia towards left and right-sided loss of pain and temperature is left-sided Wallenberg’s syndrome.

Wallenberg’s syndrome, otherwise known as the lateral medullary syndrome, is a type of ischemic stroke of the brainstem. The symptoms and the corresponding tracts affected are shown below: 

Tract affected Symptoms
Descending tract and nucleus of CN V  Ipsilateral impaired sensation over half of the face
IX and X CN Ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord(dysarthria), diminished gag reflex causing dysphagia
The nucleus of tractus solitarius Ipsilateral loss of taste
Vestibular nucleus   Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
Spinocerebellar tract Ipsilateral ataxia
Descending sympathetic tract Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis (decreased sweating)
Lateral spinothalamic tract  Impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

It can be caused by occlusion of vessels like the vertebral artery, posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), Superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries. The most commonly involved are the vertebral artery and PICA.

Other options:

Dejerine syndrome is otherwise known as medial medullary syndrome. It occurs due to occlusion of the vertebral artery or its branch. There is paralysis of the ipsilateral tongue (face is spared) and contralateral limbs, as well as impaired tactile and proprioceptive sense of the contralateral half of the body.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text:
Recently, a new latex agglutination test was approved for the screening of a disease. Calculate the sensitivity and specificity based on the table given below:
  Test +ve Test -ve
Disease+ 27 3
Disease - 5 95
questions.solution:
• Let us first reconstruct the table to indicate true (TP/TN) and false (FP/FN) positives and negatives.
  Test + Test -
Diseased 27 (TP) 3 (FN)
Not diseased 5 (FP) 95 (TN)
  • Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 and specificity is given as TN/(FP + TN) x 100
  • In this scenario, sensitivity is 90% and specificity is 95%

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: A woman presents with cyclical hematuria 8 months after an emergency cesarean section was done for non-progress of labor. There is no urinary incontinence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of vesicouterine fistula.

Vesicouterine fistula occurs during cesarean section or uterine rupture or placenta accreta. Patients complain of cyclical hematuria due to the trickling of menstrual blood into the bladder through this anomalous condition. But the urinary continence of the patient remains normal. This is also known as Youssef syndrome. 

Other causes of cyclical hematuria can be intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) perforation into the bladder or bladder endometriosis. True pathology can be confirmed by cystoscopy.

Treatment:

  • Prolonged bladder catheterization can close the fistula. 
  • Abdominal repair using omental or gracilis graft is done if the prolonged catheterization fails.

Methylene blue swab test:

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in the ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • The lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in the urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

Other options:

Option A: In a vesicovaginal fistula, the main complaint will be constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). It usually follows difficult childbirth. A positive methylene blue test confirms the diagnosis. 

Option C: Ureterovaginal fistulae result from direct injury to the ureter during gynecologic surgery (Eg: Wertheim's procedure for Ca cervix). Urine dribbles from both vagina and urethra post-surgery. The three-swab test will not stain with methylene blue, but with urine.

Option D: In urethrovaginal fistulae, the patient is continent and dry, but may dribble urine during micturition. This usually follows surgery for a paravaginal cyst or urethral diverticulum, or after a penetrating injury from a fall or criminal abortion. The fistulous opening is visible on speculum examination.

questions.text: Which of the following milestones is expected to be seen in a child at 5 years of age?

choices.text: Riding a tricycle and making a tower of 9 blocks
Establishment of handedness and parallel play

questions.solution:
At the age of 5 years, a child is expected to dress and undress themselves.

Developmental milestones at the age of 5 years include:

  • Motor - skips
  • Adaptive - Draws a triangle
  • Language - Asks meaning of words
  • Social - Dresses and undresses

Undressing is easier and hence learned before dressing.

  • 2 years - Helps to undress
  • 3 years - Helps in dressing (if helped with buttons)
  • 5 years - Dress and undress fully (without any help)

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental Milestones
At 1 year
  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months
At 2 years
  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories
At 3 years
  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children
At 4 years
  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text: A patient in acute hypoxemic respiratory failure is administered oxygen using the device shown below. Name the device.
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a high-flow nasal cannula.

High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a mode of respiratory support used to manage conditions such as acute hypoxemic respiratory failure.

There are three components to a high-flow nasal cannula:

  • A flow generator that provides a gas flow of up to 40 liters per minute
  • An air oxygen blender that increases FiO2 from 21% to 100%
  • A humidifier

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier, a nasal cannula (no. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

Other options:

Option A: Mechanical ventilator

Option B: Infusion Pump

Option C: Continuous positive airway pressure(CPAP)

questions.text: A lady comes with a reddish firm nodule on her chest which hasn't grown in size. Its histolopathological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with reddish firm nodule on her chest and histology showing multiple dilated vascular structures with a single layer of epithelial cells is suggestive of a hemangioma.

Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of hemangioma are capillary hemangioma (most common), juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma, cavernous hemangioma and pyogenic hemangioma.

Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to a large hemangioma over the eyelid).

Treatment options include:

  • Beta-blockers - oral propranolol
  • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser

The given image shows a flat to elevated, irregular, pinkish-red mass over the skin of the abdomen suggestive of a strawberry hemangioma.

questions.text: You are assisting your professor during a breech delivery. You notice that she performs the maneuver given below to deliver the extended arms of the baby. This maneuver is known as:
questions.solution:
The maneuver shown in the image is Lovset's maneuver used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Loveset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CT pulmonary angiography should be performed as it is the principal imaging test for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE).

Option A: Most patients with acute PE have normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography is a very useful diagnostic tool for detecting conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection.

Option C: Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scanning has become a second-line diagnostic test for PE, used mostly for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast or in whom the CT results are inconclusive.

Option D: MR pulmonary angiography may detect large proximal PE but is not reliable for smaller segmental and subsegmental PE. It is used when neither CT angiography nor ventilation-perfusion scan can be done. 

The images below demonstrate a pulmonary embolus (marked by arrows). The image of the gross specimen shows saddle thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese woman underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy and the specimen of gallstones removed is given below. Which of the following is least likely to be a risk factor for the formation of this type of gallstone in her?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis is not a risk factor for the formation of cholesterol gallstones. Hereditary spherocytosis leads to the production of black pigment stones.

Obesity, high-caloric diets, prolonged fasting, certain medications (e.g., oral contraceptives), and resection of the terminal ileum result in increased secretion of cholesterol and supersaturation of bile. This enhances the lithogenicity of bile.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy presented with lethargy, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. On investigation, he had elevated levels of homocysteine in blood and homocystinuria. Which of the following can lead to the above finding?
questions.solution:
Homocystinuria is caused by the following:

  • Cystathionine β-Synthase deficiency: This is classic homocystinuria. The most common inborn error of methionine metabolism.
  • Defects in methylcobalamin formation: Methylcobalamin is the cofactor for the enzyme methionine synthase, which catalyzes remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Deficiency of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase: This enzyme reduces 5,10 methylenetetrahydrofolate to form 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which provides the methyl group needed for remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.

Related Pearl: Homocystinuria

questions.text: All of the following forms the right cardiac border on the chest X-ray PA view except:
questions.solution:
On a chest x-ray PA view, the right ventricle does not form the right cardiac border.

Right cardiac border formed by:

  • SVC
  • Right atrium
  • IVC

Left cardiac border formed by:

  • Subclavian artery
  • Aortic knob/ knuckle (Aortic Arch)
  • Pulmonary artery segment
  • Left atrial appendage
  • Left ventricle

The right ventricle is the most anteriorly placed cardiac chamber. It forms the inferior border on the chest X-ray PA view.

Given below is a list of normal silhouettes on chest radiographs as seen on the PA view. The loss of these silhouettes are indicative of the site of pathology:

Obliterated silhouette Site of pathology
Right para-tracheal stripe Right upper lobe
Right heart border Right middle lobe or
medial right lower lobe
Right hemidiaphragm Right lower lobe
Aortic knuckle Left upper lobe
(posterior segment)
Left heart border Lingula segments of 
left upper lobe
Left hemidiaphragm 
or descending aorta		 Left lower lobe

questions.text:
Match the following splints and the conditions where they are used.
  1. Cervical spine injury
  2. Brachial plexus injury
  3. Radial nerve palsy
  4. Ulnar nerve palsy
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a.

  1. Knuckle bender splint - Ulnar nerve palsy
  2. Cock-up splint  - Radial nerve palsy
  3. Aeroplane splint - Brachial plexus injury
  4. SOMI Brace - Cervical spine injury

Knuckle bender splint :

In cases of ulnar claw hand where ulnar nerve recovery is anticipated, the knuckle bender splint can be used to correct and prevent MCP (metacarpophalangeal) hyperextension.

Cock-up splint - 

it is used in the management of radial nerve palsy.

Aeroplane splint:

It is used in the management of brachial plexus injury and axillary nerve injury.

SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is used to treat cervical spine injury. 

It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with a history of epilepsy. The patient's CT revealed the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is neurocysticercosis.

Neurocysticercosis is caused by the tapeworm Taenia solium. This disease is commonly seen in patients who consume undercooked pork and are from poor socioeconomic conditions. Patients present with adult-onset epilepsy and other features such as:

  • Psychiatric and behavioral disturbances
  • Visual disturbances
  • Features of increased intracranial tension, hydrocephalus

On imaging, four distinct stages of this disease can be made out:

  • Vesicular stage - This stage consists of viable larvae with scolex
  • Colloidal vesicular stage - The larva breaks down eliciting an immune response from the host
  • Granular nodular stage - After the larva dies and the cyst collapses, thick enhancing cyst walls with surrounding edema is seen
  • Calcified nodular stage - Edema resolves and small calcified lesions are seen

questions.text: A patient presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. Thyroid function tests demonstrate an elevated T4 and normal TSH. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the next best step in evaluating this patient.

A normal TSH level in this patient indicates that he/she is euthyroid. A solitary nodule in a euthyroid state needs further evaluation by USG.

USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue.

Ultrasound findings within a nodule that are considered suspicious for malignancy include:

  • microcalcifications
  • hypervascularity
  • infiltrative margins
  • being hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma

Benign nodules are easily compressible whereas malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm. Hence, benign nodules are easily deformed on applying pressure while performing USG. The malignant nodules do not deform as easily.

FNAC (Option a) is now only indicated after sonography and evidence of malignant nodules. Thyroid autoantibodies (Option c) are tested to rule out autoimmune thyroiditis in case the thyroid function tests come out abnormal. Radioactive iodine uptake test (RAIU) (Option d) is only indicated in cases of toxic adenoma, ie, nodularity with features of thyroid toxicity

questions.text: A pregnant patient in the later second trimester presents to the outpatient department with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding. She is diagnosed with the condition depicted in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image represents placenta previa.

Placenta previa is a condition characterised by partial or complete implantation of the placenta over the lower uterine segment. Patients commonly present with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding near the end of the second trimester or the third trimester.

The grades of placenta previa are:

  • Type—I (Low-lying): A significant portion of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and there is no encroachment of the os
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially.
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: Identify the mode in USG.
questions.solution:
The USG image represents M-mode used for echocardiography. Echo intensity is represented as brightness and trace is swept across the screen so that the x-axis represents time.

Modes in USG:

  1. A mode – amplitude mode is used in ophthalmology and orbital biometry 
  2. B mode/grayscale - used for all routine applications
  3. M mode – echocardiography (motion)

The advantage of USG is that there is no radiation and it is portable. It is the safest radiological investigation in pregnancy. It is the preferred investigation for:

  • Gall bladder pathology
  • Cysts
  • Fluid collection like ascites, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion
  • Initial evaluation of jaundice

The disadvantage of USG is the operator dependence.

HIFU (high intensity focussed USG) is a therapeutic application of USG. It is useful for the treatment of fibroids. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high-powered tightly-focused ultrasound beams so that very small target tissues can be heated and coagulated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy?

choices.text: Myoclonic seizures frequently occur in morning.

questions.solution:
In juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, EEG characteristically shows 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome):

  • It is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults ( 12-18 years).
  • They are benign generalized myoclonic seizures with a good prognosis.
  • Typically, it starts in early adolescence (12-18 years), with 1 or more of the following manifestations:
    • Myoclonic jerks in the morning (“shock-like” contraction of a muscle, that is often repeated), generalized tonic–clonic or clonic seizures upon awakening; and juvenile absences.
    • Sleep deprivation, alcohol (in older patients), and photic stimulation provoke seizures.
    • The EEG usually shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges.
  • The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is valproate. Lamotrigine is also useful.
Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox–Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with diarrhoea, confusion, high-grade fever, and bilateral pneumonitis. Which pathogenic agent is suspected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of confusion, high-grade fever, and bilateral pneumonitis with associated diarrhea is highly suggestive of atypical pneumonia caused by Legionella.

Legionnaire’s disease mostly presents as atypical pneumonia. Risk factors include advanced age, immunocompromised patients, chronic smoking, and long-standing lung disease. Diarrhea (watery rather than bloody) is reported in 25–50% of cases. The most common neurologic abnormalities are confusion or changes in mental status.

Urine for legionella antigen is the preferred test. Drugs of choice are azithromycin and respiratory quinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin).

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.

Normally, adrenal corticosteroids help to retain sodium and maintain normal intravascular volume. Sudden lack of these hormones causes:

  • Excessive loss of sodium
  • Decreased intravascular volume
  • Low blood pressure
  • Circulatory collapse

Primary causes of Addisonian crisis include:

  • Adrenal haemorrhage
  • Acute infection

Secondary causes of Addisonian crisis include:

  • Surgery
  • Cessation of steroid therapy
  • Postpartum pituitary necrosis.

Treatment includes fluid and glucocorticoid replacement.

Other options:

  • SIADH is a syndrome characterized by euvolemic hyponatremia due to a primary defect in osmoregulation. The causes of SIADH include neoplasms of the lung, duodenum, pancreas, ovary, head trauma, infections (tuberculosis, meningitis, pneumonia), and drug overdose (vasopressin, desmopressin).
  • Diabetes insipidus patients present with polyuria and polydipsia.
  • Cerebral salt wasting disease - Urine osmolality will be high.

 

Differentiating features of DI,Psychogenic polydypsia, SIADH & Cerebral salt wasting disease:

Parameter Diabetes insipidus Psychogenic polydipsia SIADH Cerebral salt wasting
clinically Polyuria Polydipsia Polydipsia Well hydtrated patient Dehydrated hypotensive patient
Plasma volume ↓ Slightly ↑ ↑ ↓
Plasma Na+ ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
Plasma Osmolality ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
Urine Osmolality ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑↑
Urine volume ↑ ↑ ↓ Initially ↑, later ↓
Plasma ADH ↓ ↓↓ ↑ ↓
Plasma aldosterone Normal Normal ↑ ↓
 ↑ - Increased; ↓ - Decreased

questions.text: An adolescent patient presents to the outpatient department with the findings shown in the image below. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this patient is acne vulgaris. The microorganism that is commonly implicated is Propionibacterium acnes.

Acne vulgaris is an inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. This disease most commonly involves the face. Patients present with multiple open or closed comedones, papules, pustules, and nodules of varying degrees and depths.

Topical retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, and topical clindamycin are used in the management.

Related Pearl: Important Syndromes Related to Acne

Important Syndromes Related to Acne

I. SAPHO syndrome

  1. Synovitis
  2. Acne
  3. Pustulosis
  4. Hyperostosis
  5. Osteitis

II. HAIR-AN syndrome

  1. Hyperandrogenism (HA)
  2. Insulin Resistance (IR)
  3. Acanthosis Nigricans(AN)

III. SAHA syndrome

  1. Seborrhoea
  2. Acne
  3. Hirsutism
  4. Androgenetic alopecia

IV. PAPA syndrome

  1. Pyogenic Arthritis (PA)
  2. Pyoderma gangrenosum (P)
  3. Acne(A)

questions.text: A boy was brought with complaints of pain over the right flank associated with fever and chills with leukocytosis. A CT scan showed the following finding.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with flank pain, fever, leucocytosis, and a CT scan showing a mass in the psoas muscle lateral to the vertebral column is diagnostic of a psoas abscess.

Psoas abscess occurs due to a collection of pus due to an infection in the iliopsoas compartment. The compartment is retroperitoneal and hence, the abscess is a retroperitoneal abscess. The compartment contains the iliacus and iliopsoas muscles. 

Psoas abscess is either primary or secondary. Tuberculosis of the spine leading to Pott's abscess was the leading cause of psoas abscess. But, recently, the hematogenous spread of infection from an occult primary site (gastrointestinal or urinary tract) has become common, especially in immunocompromised patients and the elderly. It can also occur due to contiguous extension of infection from neighboring structures.

Clinical features include:

  • Back pain and fever.
  • Soft, fluctuant swelling pointing towards the groin (hip).
  • Pain on passive hip extension or active flexion of the psoas - Positive psoas sign.

Lab investigation - Leucocytosis, increases ESR and mild anemia may be seen.

Diagnosis - Commonly confirmed using a CT scan. Blood culture and abscess material should be obtained in all cases to guide therapy.

Percutaneous CT-guided drainage and antibiotic therapy are useful in the treatment of the condition. 

Radiological images showing psoas abscess (mass lateral to the vertebral column).

questions.text: An incidental ovarian mass is found when evaluating a 19-year-old girl for kidney stones. The mass is removed and its contents are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with an asymptomatic ovarian mass consisting hair, bone, and sebaceous material is a mature teratoma. 

Teratomas are germ cell tumors. They contain embryonic tissues leading to the differentiation of cells along these pathways. There are three classes of teratomas:

  • Mature (benign) teratomas (eg: Dermoid cyst)
  • Immature (essentially malignant) teratomas (eg: solid teratoma)
  • Monodermal (highly specialized) tumors (eg: Struma ovarii)

Mature cystic teratoma, also known as dermoid cysts are unilocular in structure and have a smooth surface. They usually are lined by squamous epithelium with hair follicles leading to the formation of sebaceous material and hair. Other structures like teeth, bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and mucous membranes can also be found. 

Most patients are asymptomatic. Some patients may have symptoms because of the mass size of the teratoma. In other patients, ovarian teratomas can result in torsion of the ovary. Other rare complications include rupture of the cyst and spillage of contents into the abdominal cavity. 

Treatment of mature teratomas involves excision in order to prevent complications. Otherwise, mature teratomas are generally innocent. 

Other options: 

Option A - Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. 

The following image shows both mature (left) and immature teratomas (right). 

Option C - Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism. 

Option D - Granulosa cell tumors arise from the sex cords of the gonads. They are solid and generally produce estrogen. They can cause precocious puberty in children, hyperestrogenism in adults, and post-menopausal bleeding. They vary in appearance and range from microscopic to large, solid and cystic, encapsulated masses. If hormonally active, they may be yellow due to intracellular lipids.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the OPD with a painless deformity. A radiograph of the child's legs is shown below. The most common cause of this deformity is ______.
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows bowing of legs in the child. The most common cause of this deformity is rickets.

In toddlers, bow leg or genu varum is one of the most common initial sign of rickets. In older children, genu valgum or coxa vara might be present.

The characterisric features of rickets include:

  • Delayed closure of the fontanelles
  • Frontal bossing
  • Craniotabes - soft skull bones
  • Rickety rosary - enlargement of the costochondral junction
  • Harrison sulcus 
  • Pigeon chest or pectus carinatum

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with sudden palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, intense fear, and a feeling like she is being choked. She was diagnosed with diabetes and started on metformin 1 month ago. Patient fears that she might lose both her lower limbs because of diabetes. Physical examination, ECG, and laboratory workup were unremarkable and her blood sugars were well controlled. This is the first time she is experiencing an episode like this which lasted for around 20 minutes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient experiencing sudden palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, intense fear, and a feeling of being choked without any physical or biochemical abnormalities is a panic attack.

A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that may last from minutes to hours. Recurrent panic attacks are termed panic disorders.

Panic attacks can occur in other disorders, particu­larly in specific phobias such as agoraphobia, social phobias, and post-traumatic stress disorder. 

These attacks are often unprovoked and not associated with any identifiable social stimulus. In some patients, with a history of panic attacks, there is also an underlying psychiatric anomaly such as depressive disorder.

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Disorder 
Feature
Panic disorder
Recurrent and unexpected panic attacks with ≥ 4 of the following:
  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating
  • Dizziness
  • Chest pain
  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms
  • Feeling that something catastrophic is
    about to happen.
Occur spontaneously without overt precipitants.
 
They often avoid situations/ places in which panic attacks have occurred.

Treatment is with benzodiazepines or SSRI/ SNRI and cognitive behavioural therapy
Phobias
Exaggerated anxiety responses that occur
during exposure to relatively innocuous stimuli or situations.
Specific phobias entail phobic responses to
particular stimuli or situations.
Social
anxiety disorder (Social phobia)
Phobic responses to specific to social situations.
Generalized anxiety disorder
Excessive worry about
a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.
 
3 or more of the following symptoms:
  • Restlessness
  • Fatigue
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Irritability
  • Muscle tension
  • Sleep disturbance

Treatment:

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

Second-line: Benzodiazepines, Buspirone

questions.text: A 70-year-old chronic smoker presents with a history of intermittent crampy lower abdominal pain and episodic diarrhea that has progressively worsened over the past 2 weeks. Examination revealed tenderness in the right iliac fossa and a positive guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this given case scenario is Crohn's disease.

This patient's history is suggestive of ileocolitis which commonly presents as recurrent episodes of right lower quadrant pain and diarrhea. The most common site of inflammation in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum. 

The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of ulcerative colitis.  

Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, smoking is seen to have a protective effect in ulcerative colitis.

Other options-

Option B- Diverticulitis occurs in the sigmoid colon, therefore they have left-sided signs and symptoms. 

Option D- Irritable bowel syndrome is not characterized by bowel inflammation and is a diagnosis by exclusion.

questions.text: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. Which of the following is false about the reflex elicited here?

choices.text: Occurs due to pressure at the external os of cervix
It is associated with increased level of PGF2α
Artificial rupture of membranes initiates this reflex
It is an example of positive feedback mechanism

questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is being depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. It is also known as the fetal ejection reflex and is seen due to the pressure at the internal os of the cervix.

Other options:

  • It is associated with an increase in blood levels of a prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost. This is released due to mechanical stretching of the internal os. This enhances the uterine activity and causes release of more prostaglandins. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.
  • The Ferguson reflex can be initiated by various means, including artificial rupture of the amniotic membranes (amniotomy). When the amniotic sac is ruptured, it can lead to cervical stretching and stimulate the reflex, which, in turn, can result in uterine contractions.
  • The Ferguson reflex is indeed an example of a positive feedback mechanism. In positive feedback, the response to a stimulus amplifies the stimulus rather than counteracting it. In the case of the Ferguson reflex, the initial stretching of the cervix leads to uterine contractions, which, in turn, lead to further cervical stretching and stronger contractions, ultimately culminating in childbirth. This is a classic example of a positive feedback loop.

questions.text:
A young male patient presents with breathlessness. Further questioning reveals that he had a panic attack an hour ago and has been breathless since. An arterial blood gas analysis (ABG) sample was taken and the values are given below. What is the interpretation?

pH: 7.50

HCO3: 22mEq/L

pCO2: 31 mm Hg.

pO2: 75 mm Hg.
questions.solution:
The correct interpretation of the acid-base abnormality in this patient who has been hyperventilating since morning would be respiratory alkalosis. 

In the given question,

pH is increased (normal pH - 7.35 to 7.45 )

pCO2 is decreased (normal pCO2 - 35 to 45 mm Hg)

HCO3- is normal (normal HCO3-  22 mEq/L to 28 mEq/L)

During panic attacks, there is alveolar hyperventilation. This leads to decreased PaCO2 and increased pH. If hypocapnia persists for more than 2-6 hours, then there would be a further decrease in renal filtered HCO3- reabsorption, and a decrease in renal ammonium and titrable acid excretion. 

Respiratory alkalosis leads to decreased blood flow, further resulting in dizziness, mental confusion, and seizures. This may occur in the absence of hypoxemia. Respiratory alkalosis may be seen in critically ill patients and before the onset of rapid respiratory failure. 

Other options:

Option B. In respiratory acidosis, the pH is decreased while pCO2 is increased. 

Option C. In metabolic acidosis, pH and HCO3- are decreased. 

Option D. The given values are not that of a normal ABG. Normal ABG values are as follows: 

pH - 7.35 - 7.45

PaO2 - 75 - 100 mmHg

PaCO2 - 35 - 45 mmHg

HCO3- - 22-26 mEq/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Diarrhoea

Vomiting

Hyperaldosteronism

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

Guillain- Barre syndrome, Polio, ALS, multiple sclerosis

Airway obstruction

Adult respiratory distress syndrome, COPD

Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

High altitude

Psychogenic

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3

Respiratory acidosis

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

questions.text: A patient comes to the clinic with complaints of pain in the lateral aspect of the right breast for the past 5 days. On examination, the following finding is noted under her breast. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein.

Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast.

It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Tietze’s syndrome (option A) is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Zuska disease (option B) is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Stewart–Treves Syndrome (option D) is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: You are an intern evaluating a 2-year-old girl child for malnutrition. The measurement with the WHO standard mid-upper-arm-circumference (MUAC) tape shows yellow. This reading would correspond to?
questions.solution:
The yellow colour on the new WHO standard mid-upper arm circumference of (MUAC) tape correlates to a MUAC of  11.5 to 12.5 cm.

MUAC tape cut-offs:

Colour Measurements Indication
  Red   < 11.5 cm Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM)
 Yellow   11.5 to 12.5 cm Under-nourished
  Green   > 12.5 cm Normal

Mid-upper arm circumference is used in children between 6 to 60 months. It is measured between the acromion and olecranon process and is an age-independent parameter. 

WHO update:

A higher cut-off of 11.5 cm was recommended by the WHO. According to the new update, UNICEF started the supply of new MUAC tapes as described above.

Alternative methods for evaluating malnutrition:

Bangle Test - It has an internal diameter of 4 cms. Normally, it should not cross the elbow.

QUAC stick test - It is given by the formula - Mid-upper arm circumference/ Height of child

Skinfold thickness: It is an age-independent parameter. Routinely, we measure the triceps skinfold thickness. It is measured with the help of Harpenden calliper.

  • Normal: 10 mm
  • Severe malnutrition: < 6 mm

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman came with complaints of abdominal pain, shortness of breath, and vomiting for a few hours. She is on ovulation induction therapy for infertility.  Her sonogram of both ovaries is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the sonogram showing enlarged ovaries meeting in the midline having large cysts are suggestive of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. 

Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is an iatrogenic complication seen during the luteal phase or early pregnancy. It is seen in patients taking ovulation induction therapies for infertility more common in FSH/LH therapy than clomiphene or pulsatile GnRH therapies. 

The pathogenesis in OHSS is the increased vascular permeability leading to a fluid shift from intravascular to extravascular space.

They often present with shortness of breath, abdominal pain, and gastrointestinal disturbances like nausea, vomiting, and oliguria. Abdominal pain occurs due to ovarian enlargement and accumulation of peritoneal fluid. Increased vascular permeability and loss of fluid, protein, and electrolytes into the peritoneal cavity cause ascites and result in hemoconcentration. Hemoconcentration causes hyperviscosity and leads to hypercoagulability. Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, leukocytosis, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion can be associated with OHSS. 

This condition can be prevented by

  • Withholding hCG in a cycle if there are more than 20 follicles on ultrasound and E2 level rises to 3000 pg/ mL.
  • Albumin 5% infusion in 500 mL lactated Ringer’s solution during and after oocyte retrieval
  • Dopamine agonist cabergoline 0.5 mg daily for 8 days starting on day 1 of hCG.

OHSS is primarily managed with general supportive care. Paracentesis is performed to ameliorate abdominal discomfort and relieve respiratory discomfort.

Other options:

Option B- Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is the most common endocrine disorder of the reproductive age group. Patients with PCOS present with menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, acne, infertility, etc.

The ultrasound examination image shown below is of PCOS showing enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts. 


Option C- Hyperreactio luteinalis is a condition in which one or both ovaries develop multiple large theca lutein cysts. They are commonly seen in gestational trophoblastic disease, multiple gestational pregnancies, and other high HCG states. Most of them resolve spontaneously after delivery. Surgical management is only required if it is complicated by torsion or hemorrhage. 

The below image shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple theca luteal cysts as in hyperreactio luteinalis.


Option D- Hematometra is a condition in which menstrual outflow obstruction traps the blood and distends the uterus.  A large uterus can compress the urinary bladder, and rectum causing urinary retention and constipation. blood may get infected and lead to pyometra causing fever and leukocytosis.

The below ultrasonographic image shows a smooth, symmetric hypoechoic enlargement of the uterine cavity suggestive of hematometra.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the casualty. A patient is admitted to the hospital for the treatment of acute pancreatitis. Your resident asks you to calculate Ranson's score to predict the severity of pancreatitis. All of the following parameters you would include in the assessment except:
questions.solution:
Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) > 350 IU/L is included in Ranson’s criteria, not 250 IU/L.

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Non-gallstone pancreatitis:

At presentation

  • Age >55 years
  • Blood glucose level, >200 mg/dL
  • White blood cell count, >16,000 cells/mm3
  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase level, >350 IU/L
  • Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level >250 IU/L

After 48 hours of admission

  • Hematocrit: decrease >10%
  • Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL
  • Base deficit >4 mEq/L
  • Blood urea nitrogen level: increase >5 mg/dL
  • Fluid requirement >6 L
  • PaO2 <60 mm Hg

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Gallstone Pancreatitis:

At presentation

  • Age >70 years
  • Blood glucose level, >220 mg/dL
  • White blood cell count, >18,000 cells/mm3
  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase level, >400 IU/L
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase level, >250 IU/L

After 48 hours of admission

  • Hematocrit: decrease >10%
  • Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL
  • Base deficit >5 mEq/L
  • Blood urea nitrogen level: increase >2 mg/dL
  • Fluid requirement >4 L
  • PaO2: Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

questions.text: A  female patient presents with severe abdominal pain and vomiting which was provisionally diagnosed as intestinal obstruction. An emergency laparotomy was done and the following specimen was removed. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of a trichobezoar, suggests a diagnosis of trichophagia.

Trichophagia is the compulsive eating of hair associated with trichotillomania. Trichotillomania is a form of obsessive-compulsive disorder that is associated with hair pulling. In trichophagia, people also ingest the hair that they pull. 

Complications of trichotillomania include:

  • trichobezoars
  • malnutrition
  • intestinal obstruction

Trichobezoar is a foreign body found in the gastrointestinal tract as a result of accumulated ingested hair.

The modalities currently used in the management of trichotillomania are cognitive behavioral therapy and habit reversal training.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness, and reduced muscle stretch reflexes, associated with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given image showing muscle atrophy, high arch of foot, and hammer-toes which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1 is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop. The following findings are seen:

  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum's disease is a hereditary disorder of lipid metabolism. They can manifest in infancy to early adulthood with classic tetrad of:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration

They have elevated serum phytanic acid and they are autosomal recessive in nature. 

Option C- Sjogren syndrome is a chronic, slowly progressing autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. Predominately seen in middle-aged women. Majority of them present with impaired lacrimal and salivary gland function. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome is either sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy like mononeuritis multiplex and myelitis

Option D- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. The incidence increases between the age of 25 to 55 years. Chronic inflammation of ankle and midtarsal regions leads to pes planovalgus or flat feet. Other deformities seen in RA are: 

  • Swan-neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity
  • Z-line deformity

questions.text: A female patient with invasive breast cancer in the right breast is posted for modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following step is not done in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Pectoralis major is not removed in modified radical mastectomy.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy are:

  • Whole breast tissue
  • Skin over the breast tissue
  • Nipple-areola complex
  • Pectoral fascia
  • Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss)

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

Breast conservative surgery is also known as segmental mastectomy, lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, wide local excision, and tylectomy.

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Subcutaneous mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast without overlying skin.
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Axillary lymph nodes (Levels I + II ± III)
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor divided
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + Internal mammary lymph nodes
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iversion) mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Super radical mastectomy – Halsted’s + Internal mammary + Supraclavicular + Mediastinal lymph nodes

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The shown forceps have no catch and have fenestrated blades suggestive of ovum forceps.

Ovum forceps are used to remove the products of conception in dilation and evacuation without crushing the conceptus. 

The following image shows the ovum forceps. 

Other options:

Option A- Sponge holding forceps 

Option C- Lane's tissue forceps

Option D- Allis tissue forceps

questions.text: A score of 3 for motor response according to the Glasgow Coma Scale indicates _________.
questions.solution:
Motor response of 3 indicates decorticate posture or abnormal flexion to pain stimulus.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: Match the auscultatory areas of the heart from image given below
questions.solution:
The image shows the auscultation areas of the heart and option B is correctly matched. 

The auscultation areas correspond to the areas where the sounds and murmurs of the heart valves can be best heard. 

  • Mitral area- At the apex of the heart which is at the 5th Intercostal space in the midclavicular line. 
  • Tricuspid area- Lower left sternal edge in the left 4th intercoastal space.
  • Pulmonic area-Upper left sternal edge in the left 2nd intercoastal space
  • Aortic area- Upper right sternal edge in the right 2nd intercoastal space. 

An image showing the auscultation areas of the heart is shown below:

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with recent onset facial asymmetry and a lump over the roof of the mouth for the past 1 year. On examination, a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuse borders is seen over the left hard palate. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a swiss cheese pattern. Which of the following conditions is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding is suggestive of adenoid cystic carcinoma.  Facial asymmetry points to the perineural invasion of the tumor into the facial nerve, which is characteristic of adenoid cystic carcinoma.

It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland. It is a slow-growing tumor most commonly involving the parotid and submandibular glands. Histology shows a swiss cheese pattern. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. 

It has a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive growth with a high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis. The most common site of distant metastasis is the lung. Treatment involves removal of the gross tumor, with radiation therapy for the microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) presented with postprandial abdominal pain associated with vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal examination shows no tenderness or rigidity, most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Postprandial abdominal pain in a 50-year-old male with a history of CAD is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia(CMI). The most common cause of CMI is artherosclerotic disease.

The three classic symptoms pathognomonic of CMI are:

  • postprandial pain (crampy periumbilical abdominal pain within 30 minutes of meals)
  • food fear (Foods that precipitate symptoms are avoided by the patient and unintentional weight loss can result. This aversion to food is classically described as food fear)
  • significant weight loss

CT angiogram demonstrates both the arterial lesion and the patterns of collateral blood flow.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and stenting has gained acceptance as the first line of therapy for Mesenteric Ischemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with complaints of difficulty in opening his mouth, restricted tongue movements, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating food. He is a smoker and chews pan masala. On examination, scarring is present in the oral cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is oral submucous fibrosis. It is a premalignant lesion of the oral cavity, in which fibrous bands are formed beneath the oral mucosa.
Risk factors are

  • Betel nut
  • Chilli
  • Tobacco
  • Vitamin deficiency

Clinical features include ankyloglossia, trismus, soreness, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating.

Management includes intralesional steroids, vitamin supplements, and surgical excision.

Option A: Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by post cricoid web that is associated with iron deficiency anemia, glossitis, and koilonychia. It usually presents as dysphagia.

Option B: Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia appears as a white patchy lesion, that cannot be rubbed off.

Option D: Erythroplakia is seen as bright red velvety plaque in the oral cavity.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following tumors are best suited for treatment with radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Wilm's tumor/nephroblastoma is a childhood tumor of the kidneys.

It is curable and a highly radiosensitive tumor.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: While performing an inguinal hernia repair in a 3-year-old boy, you notice Meckel’s diverticulum as the content of the hernial sac. What is this hernia called?
questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum found in inguinal or femoral hernial sacs is known as Littre's hernia. It can cause intestinal obstruction.

Option A: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option B: Narath’s hernia is seen in patients with congenital dislocation of the hip. It is a femoral hernia seen behind the femoral vessels.

Option C: Cloquet’s hernia is a type of femoral hernia where the sac lies under the pectineus fascia.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to you with a history of six weeks of amenorrhea and a recent history of vaginal bleeding mixed with a gelatinous fluid. Ultrasound revealed the following appearance. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is a hydatidiform mole.

It is a disease of the placenta characterized by proliferation of the trophoblasts and stromal edema.

Patients present with vaginal bleeding following 1-2 months of amenorrhea. The blood may be mixed with gelatinous fluid from ruptured cysts. Advanced cases may have nausea, vomiting, hyperthyroidism, and iron deficiency anemia.

On ultrasound, these patients demonstrate a characteristic snowstorm appearance. Management of this condition involves termination of the pregnancy followed by regular monitoring of beta HCG levels.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
