questions.text: A 30-year-old female, married for the past 5 years, presents with complaints of inability to conceive despite regular intercourse.  Physical examination is unremarkable. Semen analysis of the husband revealed no abnormalities. Hysterosalpingography reveals the following picture. The anomaly shown in the image below falls under which category of the american fertility society classification of mullerian duct anomalies?
questions.solution:
The image shows a hysterosalpingogram of a unicornuate uterus, which falls under Class II of Mullerian duct anomalies

In the unicornuate uterus, the formation of the uterus and fallopian tube occurs entirely from one Mullerian duct due to developmental arrest of other Mullerian ducts. On Hysterosalpingography, the endometrial cavity usually appears fusiform shape tapering at the apex and draining into a single Fallopian tube. The uterus generally appears shifted off the midline.

The AFS (American Fertility Society) classification of Mullerian duct anomalies is as follows:

  • Class I—Mullerian agenesis or hypoplasia.
  • Class II—Unicornuate uterus, with absent or defective development of one Mullerian duct.
  • Class III—Uterus didelphys
  • Class IV—Bicornuate uterus 
  • Class V—Septate uterus
  • Class VI—Arcuate uterus

Infertility is defined as lack of conception despite 12 months of regular unprotected intercourse in women aged < 35 years old and despite 6 months of regular unprotected intercourse in women aged > 35 years old.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct

Surrogacy for treatment of infertility 

Vaginal hypoplasia is surgically corrected at the time of marriage

 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any   Uterine rupture, abortions, risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct Metroplasty (Resection of membrane and fundal recombination) Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation 
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part fused where as upper part unfused Metroplasty in selected cases  Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 

Diminished fertility, Risk of miscarriage, preterm, and malpresentation

 
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (cockscomb cervix)   Ectopic pregnancy,  cervical incompetance,  clear cell adenocarcinoma of vagina and cervix 

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A young boy with Down's Syndrome presents with large warty crusts on his hands and feet. Scaling of the skin over the face, neck and trunk is also seen. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Norwegian/crusted scabies. 

This disease occurs in patients with an inadequate immune response to the mite, allowing it to multiply in huge numbers.

It is commonly seen in patients who suffer from conditions such as dementia, and Down's syndrome. It is speculated that patients with these conditions develop crusted scabies due to their lack of appreciation of pruritus.

Patients commonly present with large warty crusts on their hands and feet. Palms and soles may be irregularly thickened and fissured. There may be scaling of the face, neck, scalp, and trunk.

Related Pearl: Difference between classic and neonatal scabies

  Classic scabies Neonatal scabies
Site of involvement Interdigital webs, trunk, genitals, flexors, sparing of palms and soles, and skin above neck Face, scalp, palm, and soles
Morphology of Lesion Papules, pustules, excoriation, eczematization, burrow Vesicles, pustules, bullae, erosions, and ulcerations
Burrows Present Usually absent

questions.text: Soon after the administration of an epidural block with 1.5 % lignocaine with epinephrine, your patient went into bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea soon after the administration of an epidural block suggests accidental subarachnoid (intrathecal) injection resulting in total spinal anaesthesia.

Salient features of total spinal anesthesia:

  • Occurs following attempted epidural/caudal anesthesia if there is accidental intrathecal injection
  • Rapid onset, as the anesthetic required for epidural and caudal anesthesia, is 5–10 times that required for spinal anesthesia
  • High spinal anesthesia extends to involve cranial nerves
  • Accompanied by hypotension, bradycardia, apnea, and loss of consciousness

Prevention:

  • Careful aspiration for CSF (to rule out intrathecal placement) and blood (to rule out intravascular placement) before injecting the local anesthesia
  • Use of a test dose with lidocaine and adrenaline
  • Incremental injection techniques instead of a bolus dose

Treatment:

  • Maintaining an adequate airway and ventilation and supporting the circulation

Other options: 

Option A - Accidental subdural injection manifests after 15-20 minutes with features similar to a high spinal blockade.

Option C - Accidental intravascular injection manifests as systemic toxicity with CNS and CVS symptoms.

Option D - Allergic manifestation presents with hives, angioedema, and bronchospasm.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampatti class of this patient.
questions.solution:
The image shows Mallampatti class II airway.

The modified Mallampatti classification is used in the assessment of airway. It is a predictor of the difficulty of intubation or difficult airway.

The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without saying "ahh."

Modified Mallampati classification:

  • Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis. 
  • Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible.
  • Class II: Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible.
  • Class III: Soft palate, base of uvula visible.
  • Class IV: Soft palate not visible at all. Only hard palate visible.

Classes 3 and 4 are difficult intubation situations.

*Note:
Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while itching. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is an epithelial tumor arising from basal cells. It is the most common type of skin cancer most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, and lobule of the ear. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation (strongest risk factor), age 40-80 years with excessive sun exposure, light-skinned people, and exposure to arsenic compounds, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and infrared light. It is more common in males than females. It is also associated with syndromes such as xeroderma pigmentosum and Gorlin's syndrome.

Features of BCC include:

  • Pearly nodule with rolled border
  • Tortuous telangiectatic vessels 
  • Surface which can get ulcerated with raised and beaded edge, often with a central depression or umbilication
  • Bleeding on minor trauma

BCC has various subtypes such as nodular (most common type), pigmented, nodulocystic, morphoeic, infiltrative, and fibroepithelioma of Pinkus. 

It is locally aggressive and can erode the bone or facial sinuses. It rarely metastasizes via lymph nodes.

The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to confusion with melanoma.

Diagnosis is confirmed by a wedge biopsy. X-ray or CT may be needed if there is a local invasion. Histology shows peripheral palisading of cells.

Treatment: 

  • Surgical: Wide excision (4-6 mm clearance) with a skin graft or flap or primary suturing 
  • Mohs' surgery for BCC close to the eyes, nose, or ear to preserve more tissue.
  • Non-surgical: Radiotherapy, vismodegib and sonedegib.

Other options: 

Option A: Dermatofibrosarcoma, also known as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, slow-growing, well-differentiated primary fibrosarcoma of the skin, associated with increased production of platelet-derived growth factor-beta. It presents as a protuberant nodule within a firm, indurated plaque that can ulcerate. They are locally aggressive tumors with high recurrence rates. Treatment is wide excision and Mohs microscopic surgery. Imatinib is used for unresectable, metastatic, and recurrent tumors. The given image below shows a DFSP near the umbilicus.

 

Option B: Marjolin's ulcer is a painless, slow-growing, locally malignant, well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in a chronic scar (burns scar, scar of venous ulcer). It presents as an indurated, non-tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the surrounding area with marked fibrosis. The ulcer can spread to the lymph nodes when it reaches the normal skin. A wedge biopsy and MRI of the region involved confirm the diagnosis. Management is by wide excision, for larger ulcers, amputation is done. The given image below shows a marjolin's ulcer of the leg.

Option D: Naevus is a common benign neoplasm caused due to mutations in the components of the RAS signaling pathway. It has various types, such as congenital naevus, blue naevus, Spitz naevus, halo naevus, and dysplastic naevus. The given image below shows a patient with multiple dysplastic nevi.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought to the pediatric outpatient department with complaints of high-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and brassy cough for the past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is croup. Infectious croup (laryngitis/laryngotracheobronchitis) is a viral infection caused mainly by the parainfluenza virus type I.

It mainly affects children between 6 months to 3 years of age. Children present with symptoms such as brassy cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, or respiratory distress.

Radiographically, tapering of the upper trachea can be visualized on a chest x-ray. This is also called the steeple sign sign.

Patients with mild laryngitis/laryngotracheobronchitis are managed symptomatically with antipyretics, dexamethasone, and inhaled budesonide. Severe croup warrants urgent inpatient admission with oxygen inhalation.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A middle aged female patient is diagnosed with insulinoma. Which of the following is not a component of the classical Whipple's triad seen in this condition?

choices.text: Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

questions.solution:
Increased levels of 72-hour-fasting insulin is not a part of the classic Whipple's triad.

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma:

  1. Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  2. Plasma glucose levels of <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL
  3. Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

Insulinoma is a neuroendocrine tumor in which patients present with hypoglycemia due to inappropriately high insulin secretion.

The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

Insulinomas having a diameter of <2 cm without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Tumor enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors located within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals and octreotide or diazoxide.

questions.text: The triangle of doom is bounded by all except ___________.
questions.solution:
Cooper’s ligament does not form the boundary of triangle of doom.

Related Pearl: The triangle of doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Femoral nerve
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Related Pearl: The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

The triangle of pain/Electrical hazard zone:

It is bounded

  • Superio-medially by gonadal vessels
  • Laterally by peritoneum
  • Inferio-laterally by the iliopubic tract

Contents:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Anterior femoral cutaneous nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Femoral nerves

Related Pearl: The circle of death/Crown of death/Corona mortis:

  • It is a vascular continuation formed by the common iliac, internal iliac, obturator, inferior epigastric, and external iliac vessels.
  • Accessory obturator artery which is a branch of inferior epigastric artery, arches over Cooper’s ligament and joins the normal obturator artery and forms a complete vascular ring.
  • Injury leads to torrential haemorrhage which is difficult to control.

questions.text: A primigravid woman at 34 weeks of gestation was taken for emergency cesarean section after presenting with premature rupture of membranes and severe abdominal pain. Laparotomy revealed patches of dark port wine color over the uterus. In which of the following conditions can this complication be expected?
questions.solution:
The laparotomy finding is suggestive of uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus, and this complication can be expected in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total placental separation from its implantation site before delivery. The bleeding may be:

  • Revealed (blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix) or
  • Concealed (blood accumulates between detached placenta and uterus)

Risk factors for abruptio placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. Patients often present with sudden onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.

Uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus is a complication seen in severe types of concealed abruptio placentae. There is massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature, potentially extending up to the serous coat. It is only diagnosed on laparotomy, where a port-wine-colored uterus (diffuse or patchy) is seen. Though the uterus may lose its contractility, increasing the risk of bleeding, it rarely causes uterine atony. Hence, Couvelaire uterus does not require hysterectomy until uterine atony occurs.

Other complications of abruptio placenta include: 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Hypovolemic shock due to torrential bleeding
  • Acute kidney injury

Abruptio placenta is mostly managed by immediate delivery and management of complications such as shock with adequate blood products.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very near to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition.

Option B: Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder that occurs after 20 weeks due to the new onset of hypertension and proteinuria. Patients complain of headaches, epigastric pain, decreased urine output, and blurring of vision.

Option D: Uterine inversion is a complication that occurs in the third stage of labor. The uterus is partially/completely turned inside out due to various factors, such as fundally implanted placenta, uterine atony, placenta accrete syndrome, and cord traction before the placenta is separated. It produces acute lower abdominal pain with a bearing down sensation and leads to massive bleeding.
